signature.name: Final Draft 5-7
signature.note: BOF: 0xFDFDFDFD {12-64} string 'Final Draft, Inc'

details.dc:description: Final Draft is screenwriting software for writing and formatting screenplays. This entry concerns the native file format of versions 5 through 7.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Hull History Centre / Hull History Centre

signature.name: Music Encoding Initiative
signature.note: BOF: ASCII header - <?xml version="1.0" , followed by mei namespace declaration xmlns="http://www.music-encoding.org/ns/mei Schema: http://music-encoding.org/downloads/latest-release/

details.dc:description:
The Music Encoding Initiative (MEI) is an open-source effort to define a system for encoding musical documents in a machine-readable structure. MEI is formalised in the MEI schema, a core set of rules for recording physical and intellectual characteristics of music notation documents expressed as an eXtensible Markup Language (XML) schema.
PRONOM currently does not distinguish between different versions of MEI.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Bibliothèque cantonale et universitaire - Lausanne / Bibliothèque cantonale et universitaire - Lausanne

signature.name: Apple Double Resource Fork (v1)
signature.note: BOF: 4 byte AppleDouble Magic Number 0x00051607, then 4 byte version number 0x00010000

details.dc:description:
The resource fork is a construct of the Mac OS operating system used to store structured data in a file, alongside unstructured data stored within the data fork. The format specification is available here: http://support.apple.com/kb/TA32537?viewlocale=en_US
The format lacks an extension, and is instead represented by a file name consisting of ._<filename resource fork belongs to>
details.dc:creator: Apple Computer, Inc.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: AppleSingle v1
signature.note: BOF: 4 byte AppleSingle Magic Number 0x00051600, then 4 byte version number 0x00010000

details.dc:description: Apple Computers created the AppleSingle format (as well as the AppleDouble format) to represent and preserve the attributes of files across files systems that do not support the same attributes of the file’s home systems. AppleSingle is primarily a storage format and contains both a file’s contents and attributes. It consists of a header and one or more optional data entries followed by the byte stream of the file it is storing. It maintains the original Macintosh filename and file type (e.g. Mydoc.pdf). The AppleSingle format can store a number of different kinds of formats.
details.dc:creator: Apple Computer, Inc.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: AppleSingle v2
signature.note: BOF: 4 byte AppleSingle Magic Number 0x00051600, then 4 byte version number 0x00020000

details.dc:description: Apple Computers created the AppleSingle format (as well as the AppleDouble format) to represent and preserve the attributes of files across files systems that do not support the same attributes of the file’s home systems. AppleSingle is primarily a storage format and contains both a file’s contents and attributes. It consists of a header and one or more optional data entries followed by the byte stream of the file it is storing. It maintains the original Macintosh filename and file type (e.g. Mydoc.pdf). The AppleSingle format can store a number of different kinds of formats.
details.dc:creator: Apple Computer, Inc.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: RTF 0
signature.note: BOF: {\rtf0 version control word & any character set control word from /ansi /mac /pc /pca

details.dc:description:
Rich Text Format (RTF) is a format developed by Microsoft to encode formatted text and graphics for use within applications or for data and formatting transfer between applications. It is closely associated with Microsoft Word, and new versions are developed with each release of Word. RTF files are encoded in plain text, typically ASCII, and consists of a series of control words, control symbols and groups. An RTF file comprises a Header section, containing various header tables, followed by a Document section, containing the document content and formatting.
RTF0 may predate version 1.0 of the RTF specification which is known to date from at least 1992. Please contact the PRONOM team if you are aware of or have access to a formal specification for RTF0.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

details.dc:description: Windows Movie Maker is video editing software by Microsoft. A .mswmm file won't typically contain any source audio or video data, rather it will contain references or pointers to the source data. For this reason extracting a .mswmm file from its context may result in the movie being unable to play. A movie exported to a video format from within the application will contain the appropriate data for portable playback.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

You can export a single drawing or publish multiple drawings and sheet sets into a DWF or DWFx file.

details.dc:description: A MAX file is a three-dimensional scene file. They are created by 3DS Max, a 3D modeling, animation, and rendering application. It may contain multiple models that include wireframes, textures, lighting effects, shading, animation, and other 3D design elements.

signature.name: XML Property List
signature.note: BOF: <?xml version=("|')1.0("|'){8-256}<plist version="1.0">

details.dc:description: In the OS X, iOS, NeXTSTEP, and GNUstep programming frameworks, property list files store serialized objects. It is the standard way to save and load data between the internal representation within the objects defined in an Objective-C program and disk files, in order to store program settings and other data. This is the XML version but there is also a binary version of the format.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives
record_metadata.dc:description: Versions prior to DROID 6.3 may not identify this format correctly

signature.name: AAE Sidecar Format
signature.note: BOF: <?xml version=("|')1.0("|'){8-256}<plist version="1.0">{8-1024}apple.PhotoLibraryServices

details.dc:description: The AAE sidecar format is a form of property list format. It has been reported as present in iOS 8 and OS X Yosemite for transferring non-destructive adjustments in photo editing between systems and apps. It is an XML based format. The .aae file accompanies the actual image which is in a .jpg file.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

It is used for desk top publishing (DTP) with Apple's Macintosh OS X (Mac OS-X) operating system. The format is an XML Property List dictionary based format. There is also a binary version of this format.

signature.name: OneNote package file
signature.note: MSCF{20}..{1-2048}onetoc

details.dc:description: Microsoft OneNote is a computer program for information gathering and multi-user collaboration. OneNote package files are compressed container formats which allow users to share OneNote files across computers. The OneNote File Format is a persistence format for storing digital notes as hierarchical sets of sections and pages. Pages can contain text, images, tables, note tags and other types of user-defined content.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

record_metadata.dc:description: Unfortunately we are currently unable to use PRONOM to be able to develop a signature to identify this format, hopefully in the future this functionality will be available.

details.dc:description: SHA256 is part of the family of SHA-2 (Secure Hash Algorithm 2) hash functions which are designed by the United States National Security Agency. SHA256 prodcues a 256-but (32-byte) hash value. It can be used as a checksum to verify data integrity. The SHA256 file is a text document which contains single or multiple SHA1 values.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: SHA-1 (Secure Hash Algorithm 1) is a cryptographic hash function designed by the United States National Security Agency and is a U.S. Federal Information Processing Standard published by the United States NIST. SHA-1 produces a 160-bit (20-byte) hash value. It can be used as a checksum to verify data integrity. The SHA1 file is a text document which contains single or multiple SHA1 values.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: The MD5 algorithm is a hash function producing a 128-bit hash value, it is described in RFC 1321. Although MD5 was initially designed to be used as a cryptographic hash function, it has been found to suffer from extensive vulnerabilities. It can still be used as a checksum to verify data integrity against unintentional corruption. The MD5 file is a text document which contains single or multiple MD5 values.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Jeffs Image Format
signature.note: JIF99a

details.dc:description: Jeff's Image Format (JIF) is a raster image file format that was designed to be a patent-free alternative to GIF. It is nearly identical to GIF, except that it uses zlib compression instead of LZW.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: Software-Independent Archiving of Relational Databases is a format for storing content of relational databases in files for long-term preservation e.g. in archives. The format was developed by the Swiss Federal Archives. It is an open standard and is supported by the SIARD software of the Swiss Federal Archives. SIARD format is a ZIP file (based on the 64 bit extension of the ZIP format introduced by PkWare Inc. with version 4.5 of the ZIP format definition in order to avoid size limitations which are unrealistic for databases). The ZIP file contains an XML file describing the database structure and metadata as well as a collection of XML files describing the table content (database primary data) as well as, optionally, some text files and some binary files representing database large objects (BLOBs and CLOBs).
details.dc:creator: Swiss Federal Archives / Swiss Federal Archives

signature.name: SPSS Portable
signature.note: From the format description (http://www.gnu.org/software/pspp/pspp-dev/html_node/Portable-File-Header.html): "The first 200-byte segment is divided into five 40-byte sections, each of which represents the string charset SPSS PORT FILE in a different character set encoding, where charset is the name of the character set used in the file, e.g. ASCII or EBCDIC. Each string is padded on the right with spaces in its respective character set." The order is: EBCDIC, 7-bit ASCII, CDC 6-bit ASCII, 6-bit ASCII, Honeywell 6-bit ASCII.

details.dc:description: SPSS (Statistical Package for the Social Sciences) is a software package used for statistical analysis in the social sciences. The portable data format is designed for data transfer between differing operating systems and versions of SPSS.

signature.note: BOF: 32 byte binary magic {7} 0x32 = Windows {116} 'DATA' Signature based extensively on unofficial description of DATA format, plus a wide variety of format samples: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/sas7bdat/vignettes/sas7bdat.pdf

details.dc:description: SAS (Statistical Analysis System) is a statistical analysis software suite developed by SAS Institute. A SAS data file is a type of SAS data set that contains data values and descriptor information. This generic entry applies where PRONOM is unable to be specific regarding the version number of the file format. Please contact the PRONOM mailbox if you encounter a 'generic' SAS data file as this will help improve the data within PRONOM.

signature.name: SAS Catalog (Windows) Generic
signature.note: BOF: 32 byte binary magic {7} 0x32 = Windows {116} 'CATALOG' Signature based extensively on unofficial description of DATA format, plus a wide variety of format samples: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/sas7bdat/vignettes/sas7bdat.pdf

details.dc:description: SAS (Statistical Analysis System) is a statistical analysis software suite developed by SAS Institute. SAS catalogs store many different kinds of information in smaller units called catalog entries. Each entry has an entry type that identifies its purpose to SAS. A single SAS catalog can contain several types of catalog entries. This generic entry applies where PRONOM is unable to be specific regarding the version number of the file format. Please contact the PRONOM mailbox if you encounter a 'generic' SAS catalog file as this will help improve the data within PRONOM.

signature.name: R3D v2
signature.note: BOF, offset 4: RED2{2}R2

details.dc:description: REDCODE RAW (R3D) is a proprietary multimedia audio/video file format owned by the Red Digital Cinema Camera Company and featuring lossy compression for video contents and lossless for audio contents. It is used as native recording format of Red digital cameras and recorded on proprietary Hard Disk Drives, CompactFlash cards or SSD drives, but can be extracted from there and be trivially handled in any file-based audio/video, IT or home environments.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Redcode Metadata
signature.note: BOF: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>.<!DOCTYPE REDXIF>

details.dc:description: The Redcode Metadata File stores post-production edits of the raw media files. The original files remain untouched as the RMD file records, among other adjustments, changes to colour, white-balance, and dynamic range of the original image.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: DirectDraw Surface
signature.note: BOF: magic: 'DDS ', length of header (0x7C000000) = 124 bytes https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/bb943991(v=vs.85).aspx#File_Layout1

details.dc:description: The DirectDraw Surface file format was introduced with DirectX 7 to store uncompressed and compressed textures. The file format supports mipmaps, cube maps, and volume maps.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

signature.name: WordPerfect Graphics 2.0
signature.note: 4 byte magic (-1, 'WPC'), {4 byte offset to document start}, Product type (01 = wordperfect), File type (0x16 = graphic), Major/minor version=0200

details.dc:description: The WordPerfect Graphic file format (WPG) is primarily a vector graphic format, but it can store both bitmap and vector data. If you are able to help by supplying any additional information concerning this entry, please return to the main PRONOM page and select ‘Add an Entry’.
details.dc:creator: Corel Corporation

signature.name: Q&A Write Word Processor (WP)
signature.note: BOF: TBWP or TBTX, followed by null. TB stands for TouchBase, Symantec's original internal name for the product. WP = Word Processor including header/footer. TX = Text only. Format is described here: https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=YfkUKcyI7KIC&pg=PT439

signature.name: Q&A Write Word Processor (TX)
signature.note: BOF: TBWP or TBTX, followed by null. TB stands for TouchBase, Symantec's original internal name for the product. WP = Word Processor including header/footer. TX = Text only. Format is described here: https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=YfkUKcyI7KIC&pg=PT439

details.dc:description: Q&A was a database and word processing software program for IBM PC-compatible computers published by Symantec and partners from 1985 to 1998. Due to their age, Q&A files may lack an extension.
details.dc:creator: Symantec Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Draco
signature.note: BOF: 'DRACO', major version 1 Header defined in code: https://github.com/google/draco/blob/master/compression/config/compression_shared.h

details.dc:description: Draco is a library for compressing and decompressing 3D geometric meshes and point clouds. It is intended to provide efficient storage and transmission of 3D graphics.
details.dc:creator: Google

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Geography Markup Language 3.2
signature.note: ASCII header: <?xml version="1.0" , followed by gml namespace declaration xmlns:gml='http://www.opengis.net/gml/3.2

details.dc:description: The Geography Markup Language (GML) is the XML grammar defined by the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) to express geographical features. GML serves as a modeling language for geographic systems as well as an open interchange format for geographic transactions on the Internet. Version 3.2 introduced a new GML XML namespace and represents ISO standard 19136. Full specifications can be found at http://www.opengeospatial.org/standards/gml

record_metadata.dc:creator: Archaeology Data Service / Archaeology Data Service

signature.name: OGR GFS File
signature.note: BOF: <GMLFeatureClassList> EOF: </GMLFeatureClassList>

details.dc:description: The GFS file is used by the OGR Geography Markup Language reader to predefine dataset level information in the absense of an XML Schema definition for the feature classes within the GML file. Its purpose and syntax is described here: http://www.gdal.org/drv_gml.html

record_metadata.dc:creator: Archaeology Data Service / Archaeology Data Service

signature.name: 3DMF ASCII
signature.note: BOF: '3DMetafile (' https://hwiegman.home.xs4all.nl/fileformats/3dmf/3DMF.pdf

details.dc:description: 3DMF is the interchange format for the QuickDraw 3D software package originally created in 1995 for the Apple Macintosh. It is a three-dimensional image format which may be a representation of an individual object or a complete three-dimensional scene, which can be viewed from different angles with supporting 3D programs.
details.dc:creator: Apple Computer, Inc.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Datable / Datable

signature.note: '3DMF' Header size = 0x00000010, major version = 0x0001 https://hwiegman.home.xs4all.nl/fileformats/3dmf/3DMF.pdf

details.dc:description: 3DMF is the interchange format for the QuickDraw 3D software package originally created in 1995 for the Apple Macintosh. It is a three-dimensional image format which may be a representation of an individual object or a complete three-dimensional scene, which can be viewed from different angles with supporting 3D programs.
details.dc:creator: Apple Computer, Inc.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Datable / Datable

signature.name: Windows Journal
signature.note: BOF: 'NB*' 0x00 {4} 0x500100100200000 based on observation from a wide pool of samples

details.dc:description: JNT is the native format of Windows Journal, a notetaking application created by Microsoft for Windows operating systems starting with Windows XP. Due to security concerns Microsoft advise against using the format and have supplied a patch for removal of the application (https://support.microsoft.com/en-gb/help/3161102/update-for-windows-journal-component-removal). Microsoft also provide an update that re-installs a version of Windows Journal that highlights the security concerns (https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/3162655/windows-journal-application-for-windows). A JTP is a Windows Journal Template file, however this appears to be structurally identical to a JNT file.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: BKNAS
signature.note: BOF: 'BKNAS ' version = '1.0'

details.dc:description: BKNAS is an ASCII data format created to allow easy transfer of seismic data.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: Within Adobe Premiere and Adobe Audition, graphical waveform files may be created during the editing process. These are typically found alongside 'Conformed Audio' files that contain audio data. .pek files may sometimes be found to contain no data and have a size of zero bytes - PRONOM will be unable to automatically identify such files.
details.dc:creator: Adobe Systems Incorporated

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Scotland / National Library of Scotland

signature.name: AVCHD Clip Information File
signature.note: BOF: HDMV0100

details.dc:description: AVCHD (Advanced Video Coding High Definition) is a file-based format for the digital recording and playback of high-definition video. The Clip Information File may be created by some AVCHD video recorders and contains metadata describing the AVCHD stream.
details.dc:creator: Sony / Sony

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Scotland / National Library of Scotland

signature.name: M2TS
signature.note: BOF: offset 4, 0x47 sync byte appearing every 192 bytes from hereon. https://www.google.ch/patents/US7106946

details.dc:description: M2TS is the video stream packet format used on Blu-ray discs. M2TS is similar to fmt/585 - MPEG-2 Transport Stream, but instead features 192 byte packets, with a 4 byte TP_extra_header preceeding each 188 byte transport packet. Filenames usually take the form 'xxxxx.mts' or xxxxx.m2ts' where xxxxx represents a numeric value, beginning with 00000 and incrementing by 1 for each stream.
details.dc:creator: Sony / Sony

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Scotland / National Library of Scotland

signature.name: SNAP Main data file
signature.note: SNAP Main data file

details.dc:description: Snap Survey provides a selection of software which allows users to design surveys. The SNAP Meta Data file is generated and is used to build and manage the survey.
details.dc:creator: Snap Survey Enterprise

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: SNAP Archive data file
signature.note: S.u.r.v.e.y{0-64}.a.r.c.h.i.v.e. .f.i.l.e.

details.dc:description: Snap Survey provides a selection of software which allows users to design surveys. The SNAP Survey archive file is an compressed version of the SNAP Meta Data and if one is present a SNAP Raw Data file. If it is a survey with email invitations, and responses, it also compresses system files about the current state of the mailing.
details.dc:creator: Snap Survey Enterprise

details.dc:description: Snap Survey provides a selection of software which allows users to design surveys.
details.dc:creator: Snap Survey Enterprise

signature.name: FileMaker Pro 2
signature.note: Offset 525: HBAM2001MAY84*E.Pro 2.0F! This signature may be improved with a better understanding of the format.

details.dc:description: FileMaker Pro is a cross-platform relational database application from FileMaker Inc. Early FileMaker files may lack a file format extension, particularly those created in an Apple Macintosh environment.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: Phase One Raw big endian
signature.note: BOF: MMMMRawT

signature.name: Phase One Raw little endian
signature.note: BOF: IIIITwaR

details.dc:description: Phase One is a camera manufacturer and Capture One is the accompanying software. This format contains the raw image data captured by the camera's image sensor.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Historic Environment Scotland / Historic Environment Scotland

signature.name: Phase One IIQ Raw
signature.note: BOF: II*.{4}IIIICwaR

details.dc:description: Phase One is a camera manufacturer and Capture One is the accompanying software. This format contains the raw image data captured by the camera's image sensor. IIQ stands for Intelligent Image Quality, a compressed version of the raw image data captured by Phase One camera equipment. IIQ has a choice of a 'Large' (lossless) or 'Small' (lossy) options. With further research it may be possible to distinguish between these outputs.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Historic Environment Scotland / Historic Environment Scotland

signature.name: Hasselblad 3FR
signature.note:
BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: A TIFF based format starting with Intel endian header "II*" and 0x00 then between 4 to 148 wildcard bytes followed by TIFF Make tag 0x0F01, then wildcard bytes between 8 to 512, followed by, in ASCII, "Hasselblad" tag
BOF; Offset: 1-2048; Magic Bytes: 0x000500040001

details.dc:description: Hasselblad 3FR Raw Image is a proprietary Hasselblad raw image format produced by some models of Hasselblad camera equipment. The format is based on Tagged Image File Format (TIFF) and conforms to the Exchangeable Image File Format (EXIF) standard. The format was developed in the early 2000s with the introduction of H2D 2nd generation of integrated DSLRs and as a successor to Imacon 3F raw image file format.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Historic Environment Scotland / Historic Environment Scotland

signature.name: Leaf Mosaic Raw
signature.note: BOF: Tiff big endian header 'MM' 0x002A {4-36864} 'PKTS' 0x00000001

details.dc:description: MOS is the raw image format created by some models of Mamiya Leaf camera equipment. The format is based upon the Tagged Image File Format.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Historic Environment Scotland / Historic Environment Scotland

details.dc:description: Silo is a scientific data library created by the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory. Silo can produce files based on the Portable Database format, or HDF5.

signature.note: BOF: ‰HDF VAR: _silolibinfo https://wci.llnl.gov/codes/silo/media/pdf/LLNL-SM-453191.pdf

signature.name: CUE Sheet
signature.note: BOF max offset 1024: seeking 'FILE', ' TRACK 01', ' INDEX 01 ' minutes 00-99 [30:39][30:39] ':' seconds 00-59 - [30:35][30:39] ':' frames 00-75 - [30:37][30:39]. Currently set to up to 1024 bytes between each element. These offsets and indents are not strictly defined and may need to be refined further as we encounter further examples.

details.dc:description: A cue sheet file is used to describe how the tracks within optical media are laid out and may contain further metadata. They are plain text files.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: Preferred Executable Format
signature.note: BOF: Joy!peff https://web.archive.org/web/20020219190852/http://developer.apple.com:80/techpubs/mac/runtimehtml/RTArch-91.html#HEADING=91-0

details.dc:description: The Preferred Executable Format is a file format that specifies the format of executable files and other object code for the Apple Macintosh. Files of this type may lack a format extension.
details.dc:creator: Apple Computer, Inc.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Datable / Datable

signature.name: Apple Disk Image
signature.note: EOF, 512 offset - 'koly' block header, 4 byte version (0x00000004), 4 byte size of header (0x00000200)

details.dc:description: The Apple Disk Image is a disk image format commonly used by the macOS operating system, and is distinct from the earlier Apple Disk Copy Image 4.2. Please contact the PRONOM team if you are able to provide a more thorough description of this format.
details.dc:creator: Apple Computer, Inc.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Datable / Datable

signature.name: FileMaker Pro 1
signature.note: Offset 525: HBAM2001MAY84*E.Pro 1.0F! This signature may be improved with a better understanding of the format.

details.dc:description: FileMaker Pro is a cross-platform relational database application from FileMaker Inc. Early FileMaker files may lack a file format extension, particularly those created in an Apple Macintosh environment.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Datable / Datable

signature.name: Google Document Link File
signature.note: {"url": "https://docs.google.com/open{52}doc_id{1-128}email{1-128}resource_id

details.dc:description:
Google document link files are text based files written in the format of JSON (JavaScript Object Notation). They
provide a URL link to the Google document held in Google Drive.
details.dc:creator: Google

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: AVCHD Playlist File 1
signature.note: BOF: MPLS0100

signature.name: AVCHD Playlist File 2
signature.note: BOF: MPLS0200

details.dc:description: AVCHD (Advanced Video Coding High Definition) is a file-based format for the digital recording and playback of high-definition video. The Playlist File may be created by some AVCHD video recorders and contains an ordered list of references to associated AVCHD streams.
details.dc:creator: Sony / Sony

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: AVCHD Movie Object File
signature.note: BOF: MOBJ0100

details.dc:description: AVCHD (Advanced Video Coding High Definition) is a file-based format for the digital recording and playback of high-definition video. The Movie Object file manages the play order of playlists.
details.dc:creator: Sony / Sony

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: AVCHD Index File
signature.note: BOF: INDX0100

details.dc:description: AVCHD (Advanced Video Coding High Definition) is a file-based format for the digital recording and playback of high-definition video. The Index file manages the relationships between other AVCHD files.
details.dc:creator: Sony / Sony

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: AVCHD Thumbnail Index File
signature.note: BOF: TIDX0100

details.dc:description: AVCHD (Advanced Video Coding High Definition) is a file-based format for the digital recording and playback of high-definition video. The Thumbnail Index file stores an index to AVCHD thumbails, which are JPEG files with a .tdt extension.
details.dc:creator: Sony / Sony

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: Microsoft PDB 2.00
signature.note: BOF: 'Microsoft C/C++ program database 2.00'

details.dc:description: A Program Database File stores debugging information about a compiled executable, usually created at compile-time. It stores a list of all symbols in a module with their addresses and possibly the name of the file and the line on which the symbol was declared.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Scotland / National Library of Scotland
record_metadata.dc:description: An implementation can be found here: https://github.com/Microsoft/microsoft-pdb/blob/master/PDB/msf/msf.cpp

details.dc:description: Active Server Pages (ASP) is a Microsoft server-side script engine for dynamically generated web pages. The Application Directive file defines application-specific attributes used by the ASP.NET application compiler.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

signature.name: ASP Control Directive
signature.note: BOF: <%@ Control (AutoEventWireup|ClassName|CodeBehind|CodeFile|CodeFileBaseClass|CompilationMode|CompilerOptions|Debug|Description|EnableTheming|EnableViewState|Explicit|Inherits|Language|LinePragmas|Src|Strict|TargetSchema|WarningLevel)= https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/d19c0t4b(v=vs.85).aspx

details.dc:description: Active Server Pages (ASP) is a Microsoft server-side script engine for dynamically generated web pages. The Control Directive file defines user control specific attributes that are used by the ASP.NET page parser and compiler.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Scotland / National Library of Scotland

signature.name: ASP WebService Directive
signature.note: BOF: <%@ WebService (Class|CodeBehind|Debug|Language)= https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/yt16sxzt(v=vs.85).aspx

details.dc:description: Active Server Pages (ASP) is a Microsoft server-side script engine for dynamically generated web pages. The WebService Directive file defines XML Web service specific attributes used by the ASP.NET parser and compiler.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

signature.note: BOF: "HWP Document File V3.00 " 0x1A0102030405 https://www.hancom.com/etc/hwpDownload.do

details.dc:description: Hangul is a Word Processor application created by South Korean software company Hancom. HWP is the native format. A link to the file format specification can be found here: https://www.hancom.com/etc/hwpDownload.do

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: Hangul is a Word Processor application created by South Korean software company Hancom. HWP is the native format. A link to the file format specification can be found here: https://www.hancom.com/etc/hwpDownload.do.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives
record_metadata.dc:description: This format is based on the OLE2 Compound Document Format and can be identified in DROID 6 and later via a container signature.

signature.name: TRIM Context Reference File
signature.note: BOF: [TRIM Context Reference]

details.dc:description: TRIM is an electronic document and records management system developed by Hewlett Packard. The TRIM Context Reference file contains metadata relating to a digital object and acts as a link to that object.
details.dc:creator: Hewlett Packard Company

record_metadata.dc:creator: Public Record Office of Northern Ireland / Public Record Office of Northern Ireland

signature.name: Monkey's Audio variant 1
signature.note: "MAC " {48} Compression level (1000|2000|3000|4000|5000) representing (FAST|NORMAL|HIGH|EXTRA_HIGH|INSANE)

signature.name: Monkey's Audio variant 2
signature.note: "MAC " {2} Compression level (1000|2000|3000|4000|5000) representing (FAST|NORMAL|HIGH|EXTRA_HIGH|INSANE)

details.dc:description: Monkey's Audio is a lossless audio file format created by Matt Ashland.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: FAT Disk Image
signature.note: BOF: Jump instruction bytes 1 and 3 - 0XEB{1}0x90, byte 14 = Sectors per cluster, any from 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, 64, or 128

details.dc:description: The File Allocation Table is a file system architecture used across a range of computer systems. This entry aims to capture instances where the file system has been exported as a portable disk image. It may be possible and desirable to distinguish between different types of FAT image. Please contact the PRONOM team if you can assist with this.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Scotland / National Library of Scotland

details.dc:description: A .vb file is typically a source file written in the Visual Basic programming Language. It contains Visual Basic code but doesn't have a header or mandatory elements that can be used by PRONOM for identification purposes.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Scotland / National Library of Scotland

details.dc:description: VBScript is a scripting language based on Visual Basic, developed by Microsoft. A VBScript file contains code but doesn't have a formal structure or mandatory elements that can be used by PRONOM for identification purposes.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Scotland / National Library of Scotland

details.dc:description: This entry aims to describe Exclude files that don't have a formal header or mandatory elements that can be used for automatic identification within PRONOM. The purpose of an Exclude file may be application-specific. In Visual Studio for example, the .exclude extension is added to files that are to be ignored or not included within a project. In this instance the extension .exclude is simply appended to the file and doesn't alter the internal structure of the file in any way.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Scotland / National Library of Scotland

signature.name: Scribus
signature.note: BOF: '<SCRIBUS' - this sequence captures the oldest variant to use XML tags, <SCRIBUS> approximately in use for versions 0.3-0.9.*, a later variant <SCRIBUSUTF8 approximately in use for versions 1.0-1.2.*, and an even later variant <SCRIBUSUTF8NEW approximately in use for versions 1.3 onwards. It may be desirable to split these into separate PUIDs.

signature.name: Scribus version with XML header
signature.note: BOF: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>.<SCRIBUSUTF8NEW - This variant appears to have been in use from approximately Scribus version 1.3 and later

details.dc:description: Scribus is an open source desktop publishing application originally created by Franz Schmid. Scribus document files may be compressed within a GZIP container. It may be desirable to distinguish between different versions of Scribus Document.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Alias Pix Image
signature.note: BOF, offset 4: 0x0000 (representing offset to x coordinates from end of 10 byte header), {2}, 0x0018 representing 24 bits per pixel, [!00] representing number of contiguous bytes (greater than 0) that contain the following 3 byte RGB value - https://www.autodesk.com/techpubs/aliasstudio/2010/index.html?url=WS73099cc142f4875535a241551166ac8792f-7d76.htm,topicNumber=d0e246178

details.dc:description: Alias is a Computer Aided Design software family owned by Autodesk. The Pix Image file is a raster image format produced produced by Alias. Files of this type may lack a file extension.
details.dc:creator: Autodesk Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Canadian Centre for Architecture / The Canadian Centre for Architecture

signature.name: Alias Scene Description Language
signature.note: BOF: DEFINITION{1-512}version*MODEL - This signature assumes the version is defined as a minimum but this assumption may need to be revised as further format examples are encountered. It may be desirable to distinguish between different versions. https://www.autodesk.com/techpubs/studiotools/13/PDFs/SDL

details.dc:description: Alias is a Computer Aided Design software family owned by Autodesk. The Scene Description Language file defines a 3D scene, including its models, shaders, lights, and animation. Files of this type may lack a file extension.
details.dc:creator: Autodesk Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Canadian Centre for Architecture / The Canadian Centre for Architecture

format.name: The Neuroimaging Informatics Technology Initiative File Format

signature.name: The Neuroimaging Informatics Technology Initiative File Format V2 variant1
signature.note: Offset 4: 'ni2 ' 0x0D0A1A0A https://www.nitrc.org/forum/forum.php?thread_id=2148&forum_id=1941

signature.name: The Neuroimaging Informatics Technology Initiative File Format V2 variant2
signature.note: Offset 4: 'n+2 ' 0x0D0A1A0A https://www.nitrc.org/forum/forum.php?thread_id=2148&forum_id=1941

details.dc:description: A Neuroimaging format commonly used in medical industry for the analysis of MRI data. Version 2 is an extended version of NIfTI allowing 64 bit storage and addressing.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Bodleian Library, University of Oxford / Bodleian Library, University of Oxford

signature.name: PEA Archive
signature.note: BOF: Magic 0xEA, 9 bytes include major/minor version which may be desirable to distinguish in the future. Stream Header 0x0000 'POD' 0x00 https://hwiegman.home.xs4all.nl/fileformats/pea/pea_file_format.pdf

details.dc:description: PEA (an acronym of Pack Encrypt Authenticate) is the native format of PeaZip, an open source file archiver created by Giorgio Tani.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: FreeArc Archive Format
signature.note: BOF: 'ArC' 0x01

details.dc:description: FreeArc is an open source file archiver developed by Bulat Ziganshin. The native .arc file format is not related to web archiving formats and is instead closer to a compressed zip type of archive file.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: ZPAQ Archive Format variant 1
signature.note: BOF: 7kSt{9}zpQ(0x01|0x02) - https://github.com/zpaq/zpaq/blob/master/zpaq.cpp

signature.name: ZPAQ Archive Format variant 2
signature.note: BOF: zpQ(0x01|0x02) - https://github.com/zpaq/zpaq/blob/master/zpaq.cpp

details.dc:description: ZPAQ is an open source command line file archiver developed by Matt Mahoney.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: TCR eBook
signature.note: BOF: !!8-Bit!!

details.dc:description: TCR is an eBook format developed by Psion. Please contact the PRONOM team if you can provide a more detailed description.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: XZ File Format
signature.note: BOF: 0xFD '7zXZ', 0x00 EOF: YZ https://tukaani.org/xz/xz-file-format.txt

details.dc:description: The XZ file format is intended as a single-file compression format, similar in utility to Gzip.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: yEnc File
signature.note: BOF: =ybegin line= http://www.yenc.org/yEnc-draft-1.txt

details.dc:description: yEnc is a binary-to-text encoding mechanism initially developed by Jürgen Helbing for transferring binary files in messages, such as via Usenet or email.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: HEIF
signature.note: BOF, offset4: ftyp(mif1|msf1|heic|heix|hevc|hevx) - http://nokiatech.github.io/heif/technical.html

details.dc:description: The High Efficiency Image File Format (HEIF) is an image format standard defined in ISO/IEC 23008-12 - MPEG-H Part 12. HEIF can store images, image properties, thumbnails and other derivatives, plus image metadata. It can support individual images and image sequences At this time the PRONOM identification signature does not distinguish between individual images and image sequences although this may be desirable.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Uuencoded File
signature.note: BOF: 'begin '<unix permissions mode> ' ' <file name> newline character. EOF, max offset 2: newline character 'end'

details.dc:description: Uuencoding, (Unix-to-Unix encoding) is a binary to text encoding mechanism created by Mary Ann Horton for encoding binary data for transmission in email systems.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: AutoCAD Hatch Pattern
signature.note: Top line: asterisk, then a filename (up to 31 characters) that will start with a minimum of one letter or number, followed by an optional description then a line-ending. Second line: A minimum of 5 numeric (integer or floating point) values, representing Angle, X-origin, Y-origin, Delta-x, Delta-y (further values may represent optional dashes). Origins and Deltas may be negative or positive. A comma will follow each numeric value and each line will be terminated with a line ending.

details.dc:description: A hatch pattern consists of a repeating pattern of lines, dashes, and dots, and is used within AutoCAD to represent materials to be used within the manufacture of the object defined in the CAD drawing
details.dc:creator: Autodesk Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Seattle FilmWorks Image 94A variant
signature.note: BOF: SFW94A

signature.name: Seattle FilmWorks Image 98A variant
signature.note: BOF: SFW98A

details.dc:description: Seattle FilmWorks was a mail order film processing company. Digitised photographs made by the company used a family of proprietary raster image formats known as SFW and PWP (PhotoWorks PhotoMail). The SFW format has a compressed version based on JPEG, and an uncompressed version based on BMP.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: HFS
signature.note: Offset 1024, magic 0x4244 {12}, first block of volume bitmap always 0x0003{6}, size (in bytes) of allocation blocks (4 byte multiple of 512 so byte 4 always 00, byte 3 has 'even' value)[!&01]00

details.dc:description: Hierarchical File System (HFS) is a file system developed by Apple primarily for Mac OS. Within HFS a storage volume is divided into logical blocks of 512 bytes. The Hierarchical File System groups these logical blocks into allocation blocks, which can contain one or more logical blocks, depending on the total size of the volume.
details.dc:creator: Apple Computer, Inc.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Artefactual Systems Inc / Artefactual Systems Inc
record_metadata.dc:description: This entry and identification for Hierarchical File System was a collaborative effort involving the Open Preservation Foundation, Artefactual Systems, New York Public Libraries, The University of California, Los Angeles and The National Archives.

details.dc:description: Python automatically compiles a python script before running it, the first time the script runs it will create a .pyc in the same directory as the .py file which will then be used if the script is run again to save time by not having to re-compile the code.

details.dc:description: Notebook documents are files which are produced by the Jupyter Notebook application, they consist of Python computer code as well as rich text elements. They are both human readable documents as well as executable.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: DIFFRACplus Raw Data File Format 1
signature.note: BOF: "RAW1.00", 0x00 {8} MM/DD/YY. Signnature based on the format description in the Bruker Advanced X-Ray Solutions General Area Detector Diffraction System (GADDS) Reference Manual. Also see https://github.com/scattering/scattio/blob/master/python/scattio/bruker.py

details.dc:description: This format contains the raw data produced by Bruker X-ray Powder Diffraction (XRD) Instrumentation. Please contact the PRONOM team if you are able to provide a more detailed description.

record_metadata.dc:creator: University of Edinburgh / University of Edinburgh

signature.name: DIFFRACplus Raw Data File Format 2
signature.note: BOF: "RAW1.01", 0x00 {8} MM/DD/YY. Signnature based on the format description in the Bruker Advanced X-Ray Solutions General Area Detector Diffraction System (GADDS) Reference Manual. Also see https://github.com/scattering/scattio/blob/master/python/scattio/bruker.py

details.dc:description: This format contains the raw data produced by Bruker X-ray Powder Diffraction (XRD) Instrumentation. Please contact the PRONOM team if you are able to provide a more detailed description.

record_metadata.dc:creator: University of Edinburgh / University of Edinburgh

format.name: VAMAS Surface Chemical Analysis Standard Data Transfer Format

signature.name: VAMAS Surface Chemical Analysis Standard Data Transfer Format
signature.note: String near BOF: "VAMAS Surface Chemical Analysis Standard Data Transfer Format 1988 May 4"

pattern.regex: (?s)\A.{0,16}VAMAS Surface Chemical Analysis Standard Data Transfer Format 1988 May 4

details.dc:description: The VAMAS Surface Chemical Analysis Standard Data Transfer Format is designed to facilitate interchange of chemical analysis data. The format is standaradised within ISO14976. Please contact the PRONOM team if you are able to provide a more detailed description.

record_metadata.dc:creator: University of Edinburgh / University of Edinburgh

signature.name: Origin Project Format Non-Unicode
signature.note: BOF Header, "CPYA ", Major version, "." {Minor version, Build number}, "#". A 'W64' string is sometimes present between the build number and the terminating hash character which may indicate a 64 bit file version but further research is required to confirm.

details.dc:description: Origin is an advanced plotting, graphing and data-analysis application by OriginLab. An .opj file is a full Origin project file in the OPJ format. An .ogg file contains only a graph. An ogw file contains only a workbook. An ogm file contains only a matrixbook Please contact the PRONOM team if you can provide a more detailed description of this format.

record_metadata.dc:creator: University of Edinburgh / University of Edinburgh

signature.name: Origin Project Format Unicode
signature.note: BOF Header, "CPYUA ", Major version, "." {Minor version, Build number}, 0x0A".

details.dc:description: Origin is an advanced plotting, graphing and data-analysis application by OriginLab. An .opju file is a full Origin project file in the OPJ format. An .oggu file contains only a graph. An ogwu file contains only a workbook. An ogmu file contains only a matrixbook Please contact the PRONOM team if you can provide a more detailed description of this format.

record_metadata.dc:creator: University of Edinburgh / University of Edinburgh

details.dc:description: JWS is a data format produced by JASCO Spectroscopy instruments. This entry relates to the version of the format based upon the OLE2 compound document format. Please contact the PRONOM team if you are able to provide a detailed description for this format.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: PDF 2.0
signature.note:
PDF 2.0 allows an arbitrary amount of information to appear before the PDF 2.0 data starts. For now we are setting a max offset of 4096 bytes from the BOF before we expect to see the %PDF-2.0 tag as this should encompass most use-cases and also maintain processing efficiency for any identification tools using PRONOM data. If you find this offset is inadequate please contact the PRONOM team. Also seeking EOF sequence %%EOF within final 1024 bytes.
This signature cannot currently identify files that were incrementally saved to PDF 2.0 from a previous PDF version (for example PDF 1.7), and this scenario will currently return an identification for the orignal format. Please contact the PRONOM team if you can assist with developing a signature that can account for such a use-case.

details.dc:description: Portable Document Format is a platform-independent format for representing formatted documents, originally developed by Adobe Systems Incorporated. PDF 2.0 is standardised by ISO 32000-2. A PDF file comprises a Header section, a Body section containing the objects which make up the document, a Cross Reference Table, and a Trailer section. PDF files can contain a wide variety of content, including text, images, video and audio.

signature.name: C3D
signature.note: BOF: 0x0250 (magic plus pointer to first block of parameter section), {22} a block of 270 null bytes - we're using the first ten here for signature brevity, byte at 0x203 is either 0x54, 0x55, 0x56 representing processor type. String beginning at 0x516 either POINT or ANALOG. Https://www.c3d.org/HTML/default.htm

details.dc:description: C3D, or Coordinate 3D, is a biomechanics data file format that is a component of the family of file formats developed for the AMASS photogrammetry software system. C3D format provides a means for storing 3D coordinate and analog data, together with all associated parameters, for a single measurement trial.

details.dc:description:
Markdown was created by John Gruber and Aaron Swartz circa 2004. The purpose of Markdown is to let users write clean text-based documents that do not suffer from the legibility issues of other 'markup' formats.
Markdown uses combinations of characters, for example, hashes (pound-sign), asterisks, and combination of square- and rounded- brackets to prefix or suffix parts of text. The symbols provide instructions to an interpreter. A single hash '#' for example, that prefixes a line of text is an instruction to make that line a top-level header in a formatted document. Two hashes '##' is an instruction to render, or output, a secondary header. And so on.
Ultimately the result of writing markdown is a document that can be parsed into a well-formed version of other presentation languages such as HTML or XHTML.
There is no single specification for Markdown, nor is there a single canonical output. That is, Markdown syntax could be converted into many other file types.
Further descriptions of the background of Markdown and a list of Markdown 'flavors' can be found on the Archiveteam Just Solve It File Formats Wiki: http://fileformats.archiveteam.org/wiki/Markdown
Wikipedia also provides a thorough description of Markdown and its syntax: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markdown#Standardization

signature.name: Adobe InDesign Library 4
signature.note: BOF: 16-byte GUID: 0606EDF5-D81D-46e5-BD31-EFE7FE74B71D; 8-byte string File Type: LIBRARY4;

details.dc:description: Adobe InDesign is a desktop publishing application developed and produced by Adobe Inc., first released in 1999. It is the successor to PageMaker, software previously created by Aldus Corporation in 1985, which was subsequently acquired by Adobe. It can be used to produce a number of works such as posters, flyers, brochures, magazines, newspapers, presentations and books. InDesign supports XML, stylesheets and other coding markup, providing functionality for exporting tagged text content for use in other digital and online formats. An InDesign Library is used to collect assets and other elements within Adobe InDesign that can then be shared across multiple projects.
details.dc:creator: Adobe Systems Incorporated

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: Software-Independent Archiving of Relational Databases is a format for storing content of relational databases in files for long-term preservation e.g. in archives. The format was developed by the Swiss Federal Archives. It is an open standard and is supported by the SIARD software of the Swiss Federal Archives. SIARD format is a ZIP file (based on the 64 bit extension of the ZIP format introduced by PkWare Inc. with version 4.5 of the ZIP format definition in order to avoid size limitations which are unrealistic for databases). The ZIP file contains an XML file describing the database structure and metadata as well as a collection of XML files describing the table content (database primary data) as well as, optionally, some text files and some binary files representing database large objects (BLOBs and CLOBs).
details.dc:creator: Swiss Federal Archives / Swiss Federal Archives

signature.name: Virtools File Format
signature.note: BOF: 'Nemo Fi.'

details.dc:description:
This is a group of formats created by the Virtools software application. Originally released in 1993, Virtools offered a development environment to create interactive 3D applications.
Virtools includes four format types, Composition files, Object files, Player files and Scripts files.
Virtools Composition files have an extension of .cmo, these contain an arrangement of one or more elements or associated behaviours which are assembled within Virtools. Virtools Object files have an extension of .nmo and contain one or more elements or scripts. Virtools Player files have an extension of .vmo and contain a composition that has been exported from Virtools and are read only files. Virtools Script files have an extension of .nms and contain a script or a behaviour graph.
Currently PRONOM is unable to distinguish between these four different formats, if you are able to provide any information around this format please contact pronom@nationalarchives.gov.uk.

Please let the PRONOM team know if this is desirable. The COLLADA XML element contains both an xmlns attribute and a version attribute that can be read to determine the specific version.

signature.name: Wavefront OBJ Polygonal Geometry
signature.note: BOF:0-1024 (can be unlimited preamble, but we want to anchor near the beginning of the file for most cases). Must have vertices: v <space> 3 x space separated floating point values that can have a negative value or not representing x, y, z. w is optional, line ending. Later, the vertices must have a face: f <space> 3+ integer values, can be negative, separated by space. Faces count from 1. PRONOM uses this minimally viable set, however each face can have values for ‘vertex textures’ and ‘vertex normals’ - if present, these values are separated by /. Each row ends in new line character

details.dc:description: OBJ is an ASCII format for representing 3D geometry. The OBJ format supports both polygonal objects and free-form objects. Polygonal geometry uses points, lines, and faces to define objects while free-form geometry uses curves and surfaces.

details.dc:description: DigiDoc is a digital signature format specific to Estonia. The format is based on the ETSI TS 101 903 Standard ‘XML Advanced Electronic Signatures (XAdES)’. DigiDoc corresponds to the XAdES profile ‘XAdES-X-L’. A DigiDoc container includes source files (the files that were signed) as well as signatures that are related to the signed file(s). Also every signature contains the certificate, validity confirmation and the validity confirmation service certificate. https://www.id.ee/?id=35780

record_metadata.dc:creator: J. Paul Getty Trust / J. Paul Getty Trust

format.name: Band Interleaved By Line (BIL) Image Encoding

details.dc:description: Band interleaved by line is an ASCII description file that stores the pixel values of an image in a file. It is commonly used by geospatial software. The file stores the pixel information for each line or row of the image, band by band. To be interpreted the file requires a header file (hdr). Other optional information files that can appear alongside these are colour and statistic files.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

format.name: Band Interleaved By Pixel (BIP) Image Encoding

details.dc:description: Band interleaved by pixel is an ASCII description file that stores the pixel values of an image in a file. It is commonly used in geospatial software. The file stores the data for each pixel band by band. To be interpreted the file requires a header file. Other optional information files that can appear alongside these are colour and statistic files.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

details.dc:description: Band sequential file is an ASCII description file that stores the pixel values of an image in a file. It is commonly used in geospatial software. The file stores the data for each band of an image, for example data for all the pixels for the first band is stored first, and so on. To be interpreted the file requires a header file. Other optional information files that can appear alongside these are colour and statistic files.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: FO File
signature.note: Within the first 4000 hex byte pairs 'fo:root'

details.dc:description: FO file is a XML data file containing an electronic form intended for usage in the 602XML applications. The form is a composure of the layout structure using XSL-FO, data instance and data model using generic XML elements defined in the 602XML framework. The whole electronic form structure is always embedded into a digital signature represented by XML elements of the XML Signature standard.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives of the Czech Republic / The National Archives of the Czech Republic

details.dc:description: ZFO file is a ZIP archive file containing the FO electronic form. The FO electronic form is a XML data file containing an electronic form intended for usage in the 602XML applications. The form is a composure of the layout structure using XSL-FO, data instance and data model using generic XML elements defined in the 602XML framework. The whole electronic form structure is always embedded into a digital signature represented by XML elements of the XML Signature standard. ZFO file can be password protected.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives of the Czech Republic / The National Archives of the Czech Republic
record_metadata.dc:description: This format can be identified via a container signature in DROID version 6 or later. The PRONOM database cannot currently represent container signatures.

signature.name: ZFO (Message) File
signature.note: Magic bytes http://isds.czechpoint.cz/v20/message

details.dc:description: This variant of ZFO file is container for delivered data mailbox messages provided by Česká pošta, s.p. ZFO file is a ZIP archive file (PKCS #7 Cryptographic Message File) composing of the layout structure using XML elements (envelope) and data instance encoded as Base64 (message content). The message may contain one or more attachments in the file format specified in Annex 3 to Decree No. 194/2009 Col. The whole structure is always embedded into a digital signature represented by XML elements of the XML Signature standard.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives of the Czech Republic / The National Archives of the Czech Republic

ZFO file is a ZIP archive file (PKCS #7 Cryptographic Message File) composing of the layout structure using XML elements (envelope) and data instance encoded as Base64 (message content). The message may contain one or more attachments in the file format specified in Annex 3 to Decree No. 194/2009 Col. The whole tructure is always embedded into a digital signature represented by XML elements of the XML Signature standard.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives of the Czech Republic / The National Archives of the Czech Republic

signature.name: ZFO (Proof of Delivery) File

details.dc:description: This variant of ZFO file is container for proof of delivery of data mailbox messages provided by Česká pošta, s.p. in three versions: 1. proof of delivery; 2. confirmation of delivery; 3. delivery failure. ZFO file is a ZIP archive file (PKCS #7 Cryptographic Message File) composing of the layout structure using XML elements. The whole structure is always embedded into a digital signature represented by XML elements of the XML Signature standard.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives of the Czech Republic / The National Archives of the Czech Republic

signature.name: SOSI
signature.note: BOF: Magic bytes: {0-10} ‘HODE’{0-300}’SOSI’

details.dc:description: SOSI is an abbreviation of Samordnet Opplegg for Stedfestet Informasjon, translating to Systematic Organisation of Spatial Information in English. SOSI is a file format used for exchanging digital geodata published initially in 1987 by the Norwegian Mapping Authority. The standard includes definitions for geometry, topology, data quality, coordinate systems, attributes and metadata. It is a widely used in file format for Norwegian map data.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Norwegian Unix Users Group / Norwegian Unix Users Group

SOSI is a file format used for exchanging digital geodata published initially in 1987 by the Norwegian Mapping Authority. The standard includes definitions for geometry, topology, data quality, coordinate systems, attributes and metadata. It is a widely used in file format for Norwegian map data.

details.dc:description: EDOC is an electronically certified document. A format used to protect and verify identity for sensitive files. It contains a document, maybe with additional attached files and one or more digital signatures. The file can also store metadata about the document such as creator, creation time, last modification and the format version.

signature.name: Raw Flux Image
signature.note: BOF: 'RFI{date:'

details.dc:description: The format is used to dump floppy disk images with the bbc-fdc controller. The bbc-fdc controller is a project which allows the direct connection of floppy disk drives with 34 pin ribbon cables to the Raspberry Pi for the purpose of reading floppy disks. The data stream within the file represents the magnetic flux of a disk drive reading a floppy.

record_metadata.dc:creator: SLUB Dresden / Sächsische Landesbibliothek – Staats- und Universitätsbibliothek Dresden

details.dc:description: An ESRI Code Page file is an optional file that can be used to specify the code page for identifying the character set to be used, for example UTF-8. It is part of the ESRI shapefiles used in the ArcGIS software, which stores the geometric location and attribute information of geographic features. Shapefiles are a spatial data format that can work with and be edited in ArcGIS.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: Cardfile (MGC)
signature.note: BOF: Magic bytes ‘MGC’, ‘RRG’ or 'DKO' at beginning of file. The initial versions of Cardfile have the magic bytes 'MCG'. When Cardfile updated to add OLE support the file signature changed to 'RRG'. Finally the file signature changed to 'DKO' when released as a 32-bit accessory and the character width changed in order to support unicode.

signature.name: Cardfile (RRG)
signature.note: Cardfile updated to add OLE support and the magic bytes changed to 'RRG' at the beginning of the file.

signature.name: Cardfile (DKO)
signature.note: The magic bytes changed to 'DKO' at the beginning of the file when released as a 32-bit accessory.

signature.name: WARC 1.1
signature.note: Matching WARC header. Header: WARC/1.1 CRLF. Then either 'WARC-Record-ID', 'WARC-Date', 'WARC-Type', 'Content-Length' all madatory fields that can appear in any order.

details.dc:description: The WARC (Web ARChive) file format offers a convention for concatenating multiple resource records (data objects), each consisting of a set of simple text headers and an arbitrary data block into one long file. The WARC format is an extension of the ARC file format (ARC) that has traditionally been used to store "web crawls" as sequences of content blocks harvested from the World Wide Web (…) Besides the primary content recorded in ARCs, the extended WARC format accommodates related secondary content, such as assigned metadata, abbreviated duplicate detection events, later-date transformations, and segmentation of large resources”. WARC format has been written by the members of the IIPC (http://www.netpreserve.org/) grouped within the ISO/TC46/SC4/WG12.

signature.name: Tweet JSON (Raw JSON)
signature.note: The signature assumes a starting "{" character, a terminating "}" and the JSON keys "id_str" and "retweeted". This matches the raw JSON string with no line breaks.

signature.name: Tweet JSON (Linux)
signature.note: The signature assumes a starting "{" character, a terminating "}" and the JSON keys "id_str" and "retweeted". This matches a serialization with a new line at the end of the file in linux line-endings.

signature.name: Tweet JSON (Windows)
signature.note: The signature assumes a starting "{" character, a terminating "}" and the JSON keys "id_str" and "retweeted". This signature matches the same with a windows line-ending.

details.dc:description: Tweet JSON represents the serialization of the JSON response payload of the Twitter API when requesting a single Tweet by id. Each Tweet has an author, a message, a unique ID, a timestamp of when it was posted, and sometimes geo metadata shared by the user. Each Tweet also has "entity" objects, which are arrays of common Tweet contents such as hashtags, mentions, media, and links. If there are links, the JSON payload can also provide metadata such as the fully unwound URL and the webpage’s title and description. In addition to the text content itself, a Tweet can have over 150 attributes associated with it.

details.dc:description: glTF (GL Transmission Format) is a royalty-free specification for the transmission and loading of 3D scenes and models by applications. It is an API-neutral runtime asset delivery format. glTF bridges the gap between 3D content creation tools and modern 3D applications by providing an extensible, interoperable format for the transmission and loading of 3D content. The gltf contains a JSON format that must contain a top-level "asset" property. The "asset" property must contain a "version" property with a value equal to "1.0". Full specification of the format can be found at https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF/blob/master/specification/1.0/README.md A glTF Overview can be found at https://www.khronos.org/gltf
details.dc:creator: Khronos Group / Khronos Group

record_metadata.dc:creator: Preservica / Preservica

signature.name: GLTF (Binary)
signature.note: BOF:'glTF....'

details.dc:description: glTF (GL Transmission Format) is a royalty-free specification for the efficient transmission and loading of 3D scenes and models by applications. It is an API-neutral runtime asset delivery format. glTF bridges the gap between 3D content creation tools and modern 3D applications by providing an extensible, interoperable format for the transmission and loading of 3D content. Binary glTF is a container format in which an entire glTF asset (JSON asset description, binary geometry, key frames, skins and images) can be stored in a single binary blob. A glTF Overview can be found at https://www.khronos.org/gltf .
details.dc:creator: Khronos Group / Khronos Group

details.dc:description: QuarkXPress is desktop publishing software for creating and editing page layouts that can be run on Mac and Windows operating systems. It was first released in 1987. It can be used to creating a variety of layouts, from single-page flyers to multi-media projects required for magazines, newspapers and catalogues. Versions 1-3 were available on Macintosh only, from version 3.1 a common signature is used.

details.dc:description: BDOC is a digital signature format developed in 2014 to replace the old DDOC (DigiDoc) digital signature format in Estonia. Compared to DDOC, an important modification is that a .bdoc file is in fact a ZIP container with the signed files, the signatures and the protocol control information and can be opened by any program that recognises the ZIP format.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives of Estonia / The National Archives of Estonia
record_metadata.dc:description: This format can be identified via a container signature in DROID version 6 or later. The PRONOM database cannot currently represent container signatures.

details.dc:description:
The ASiC-S container is a ZIP archive file containing set of data objects and associated signatures. It is designed to associate an advanced electronic signature with any type of data. It operates with signature and time-stamp token formats XAdES, CAdES, timestamp RFC 3161.
The container has an internal structure including a root folder for all the container content possibly including folders reflecting the content structure and a META-INF folder, in the root folder, for metadata about the content, including associated signatures.
The integrity of the data is guaranteed by the electronic signature when present or should be provided externally if only a time-stamp token is applied to the data. Privacy can be guaranteed through the use of ZIP encryption features or externally. External integrity and privacy protection can be obtained e.g. through the use of SSL/TLS or S/MIME.
ASiC-S container associates one or more signatures with a single data object.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives of Estonia / The National Archives of Estonia
record_metadata.dc:description: This format can be identified via a container signature in DROID version 6 or later. The PRONOM database cannot currently represent container signatures.

details.dc:description: BDOC is a digital signature format specific to Estonia. National BDOC 2.1 standard EVS 821:2014 http://www.evs.ee/products/evs-821-2014. The format comprises two technically different subformats. In order for end users to be able to easy differentiate between these subformats, each subformat has obtained its own file extension - .bdoc and .asice. .bdoc or BDOC-TM or ASiC-E LT-TM is the BDOC signature format with a time-mark. The RFC 2560 standard based time-marks ensure long-term proofability of the authenticity of the signature. This format has been used as a default digital signature format in Estonia since 2015. .asice or BDOC-TS or ASiC-E LT is the BDOC signature format with a time-stamp. In contrast to the LT-TM format, long-term proofability of the authenticity of the signature is ensured by the RFC 3161 standard based time-stamps. The ASiC-E LT signature is highly compliant with the international standards. One can also differentiate between the subformats by inspecting the signature0.xml file: BDOC has element "SignaturePolicyIdentifier" whereas ASICE includes element "SignatureTimeStamp".

signature.note: BOF:E†....

details.dc:description: QBB file format used by QuickBooks for their backup files. It is used to manage inventory, payroll, sales and other needs of a business. QuickBooks includes many features such as marketing tools, product and suppliers, merchant services and training solutions. QBB files are the backups files QuickBooks QBW files containing all financial records, logos, images, letters, and templates.
details.dc:creator: Intuit Inc.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: WARC 1.0
signature.note: Matching WARC header. Header: WARC/1.0 CRLF. Then either 'WARC-Record-ID', 'WARC-Date', 'WARC-Type', 'Content-Length' all madatory fields that can appear in any order.

details.dc:description: The WARC (Web ARChive) file format offers a convention for concatenating multiple resource records (data objects), each consisting of a set of simple text headers and an arbitrary data block into one long file. The WARC format is an extension of the ARC file format (ARC) that has traditionally been used to store "web crawls" as sequences of content blocks harvested from the World Wide Web (…) Besides the primary content recorded in ARCs, the extended WARC format accommodates related secondary content, such as assigned metadata, abbreviated duplicate detection events, later-date transformations, and segmentation of large resources”. The WARC format defines no internal compression, however the standard recommends the GZIP format with "deflate" where compression is desirable. WARC format has been written by the members of the IIPC (http://www.netpreserve.org/) grouped within the ISO/TC46/SC4/WG12.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Landesarchiv Nordrhein-Westfalen / Landesarchiv Nordrhein-Westfalen

signature.name: Virtual Format (Raster)
signature.note: BOF: ‘<VRTDataset raster’

details.dc:description: VRT is developed by the GDAL/OGR group and is an XML file that is used to transform source GIS datasets by the GDAL/OGR programs. It can operate on either raster or vector data sources, though the two different datasets cannot be mixed in the same VRT file. VRT driver is a raster format driver that allows a virtual GDAL dtaset to be composed from other GDAL datasets with repositioning and algorithms potentially applied as well as various kinds of metadata altered or added. VRT descriptions of datasets can be saved in an XML format normally given the extension .vrt.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Wales / National Library of Wales

signature.name: Virtual Format (Vector)
signature.note: BOF: '<OGRVRTDataSource>’

details.dc:description: VRT is developed by the GDAL/OGR group and is an XML file that is used to transform source GIS datasets by the GDAL/OGR programs. It can operate on either raster or vector data sources, though the two different datasets cannot be mixed in the same VRT file. Virtual Format is a driver that transforms features read from other drivers based on criteria specified in an XML control file. It is primarily used to derive spatial layers from flat tables with spatial information in attribute columns. It can also be used to associate coordinate system information with a datasource, merge layers from different datasources into a single data source, or even just to provide an anchor file for access to non-file oriented datasources.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Wales / National Library of Wales

details.dc:description: An Amiga Disk File is the file format used by Amiga computers and emulators to store images of disks. It is a sector by sector dump of an Amiga formatted disk. It's uses include backup, disk virtualisation and game production.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

details.dc:description: Microsoft MapPoint files is a GIS format created by the MapPoint software program. The software was designed to allow users to view, edit and integrate maps. It was discontinued in 2014.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: DeluxePaint Animation File
signature.note: BOF: Magic bytes ’LPF ’ 0x0001

details.dc:description: DeluxePaint Animation software was a 1990s graphics editor for MS-DOS and released by Electronic Arts. Uses for the pixel graphic animations created included video games. The ANM file format defines key frame based animations of a vector 3D model (with model data in a separate file). The file consists of ASCII text defining locations of ‘bones’ in the model at key frames. Complex hierarchies of 3D structures can be formed to decrease file complexity for common animations. Events can be used to chain shorter animations into longer animations.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: V-Ray Material XML
signature.note: BOF: '<vismat>' {0-128} 'renderer="vray">'

details.dc:description: V-Ray Material files define material properties for use within 3D rendering applications. This entry identifies the XML version of the format in use in versions later than 1.49. Please contact the PRONOM team if you can assist with identification of the earlier binary versions of the format.

details.dc:description: Files with the extension .dbg are often Debug files used to assist with troubleshooting. They can be generated by a range of software and may not have a clear and consistent structure between different software applications. Please contact the PRONOM team if you have a specific type of .dbg file that can be identified accurately by signature.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

details.dc:description: The PMF file is a read-only map file created with ArcMap, an application included with ESRI Desktop GIS. It can be viewed with the ArcReader application. PMF files allow the protecting of data and confidentiality by enabling the creator to limit the data views, printing, zooming and other features of a map.
details.dc:creator: Esri / Esri
