signature.name: Drawing Interchange Format 2018/2019/2020
signature.note: Header section with $ACADVER group code (AC1032), EOF marker

details.dc:description: ASCII DXF format is the ASCII encoded variant of the Drawing Interchange File Format, an exchange format for vector graphics developed by AutoDesk. They are probably the widely-used formats for exchanging vector data, and have become a de-facto industry standard. The format is owned by AutoDesk and typically changes with each release of their AutoCAD family of products. DXF files contain a tagged representation of the vector data. The structure comprises a Header section, followed by sections containing data on Classes, Tables, Blocks, Entities and, optionally, thumbnail images. Each section contains a series of data elements. each preceded by a group code tag, which indicates the type of data element.
details.dc:creator: Autodesk Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: Binary DXF 2007-2009
signature.note: File header, header section with $ACADVER group code (AC1021), EOF marker

details.dc:description: Binary DXF format is the binary encoded variant of the Drawing Interchange File Format, an exchange format for vector graphics developed by AutoDesk. They are probably the widely-used formats for exchanging vector data, and have become a de-facto industry standard. The format is owned by AutoDesk and typically changes with each release of their AutoCAD family of products. DXF files contain a tagged representation of the vector data. The structure comprises a Header section, followed by sections containing data on Classes, Tables, Blocks, Entities and, optionally, thumbnail images. Each section contains a series of data elements. each preceded by a group code tag, which indicates the type of data element. Binary DXF was first developed in AutoCAD Release 2007-2009. It should not be confused with the DXB format - this is an entirely separate AutoDesk format for binary encoding vector graphics.
details.dc:creator: Autodesk Corporation

signature.name: AutoCAD Drawing Format 2018/2019/2020/2021
signature.note: BOF 'AC1032'

details.dc:description: The AutoCAD Drawing format is a vector graphics format, and is the native file format of AutoDesk's AutoCAD family of products. The format is proprietary and AutoDesk does not make details of its structure public. The information contained here is derived primarily from the OpenDWG Alliance's reverse-engineered documentation of the format, and should not therefore be regarded as definitive. The basic structure of a DWG file comprises a header section, a drawing class definitions section, the drawing object data, a drawing object map, which contains the locations of all the objects in the drawing, and an image data section, which may contain a raster image of the drawing in either Windows Bitmap (BMP) or Windows Metafile (WMF) format.
details.dc:creator: Autodesk Corporation

signature.name: DiskDoubler
signature.note: BOF: 0xABCD0054

details.dc:description: DiskDoubler is a data compression utility for the Apple Macintosh. Individual files are compressed by the software, but their file system details do not change, meaning files subject to DiskDoubler compression retain their original names, including file extensions. As such DROID and other PRONOM-based file format identification tools may report file format mismatch for DiskDoubler-compressed files.

details.dc:description: Software company Greenstreet developed a desktop publishing product called Publisher in the early 1990s and licensed the technology to a number of other software vendors, who marketed it under a range of names. The website (http://www.bmsoftware.com/greenstreetpublisher3.htm) lists the following, which may not be exhaustive: Pressworks 2, Pressworks 2.5, Press International, GSP-Pressworks 2.03, Pressworks 2.51, Instant Home Publisher, greenstreet-Publisher 2, Fuji-Publisher, IMSI TurboPublisher 1.0, TurboPublisher2.5, Media Graphics-Publishers Paradise Page Express, Micro Vision-Vision Publisher 4, NEBS-PageMagic 1 & 2, PersonalSoft-Publications, Pushbutton-Publish, Softkey-Publisher DOS v 1 & 2, Sybex-Page, Timeworks-Publisher, Publish-It, Publish-It Lite, VCI-Pro Publisher, Wizardworks-CompuWorks, Publisher 1 & 2. This entry covers the early version of the underlying format.

The website (http://www.bmsoftware.com/greenstreetpublisher3.htm) lists the following, which may not be exhaustive: Pressworks 2, Pressworks 2.5, Press International, GSP-Pressworks 2.03, Pressworks 2.51, Instant Home Publisher, greenstreet-Publisher 2, Fuji-Publisher, IMSI TurboPublisher 1.0, TurboPublisher2.5, Media Graphics-Publishers Paradise Page Express, Micro Vision-Vision Publisher 4, NEBS-PageMagic 1 & 2, PersonalSoft-Publications, Pushbutton-Publish, Softkey-Publisher DOS v 1 & 2, Sybex-Page, Timeworks-Publisher, Publish-It, Publish-It Lite, VCI-Pro Publisher, Wizardworks-CompuWorks, Publisher 1 & 2. This entry covers a later version of the underlying format, based upon OLE2.

signature.name: XLD4 (Bitmap Image)
signature.note: BOF: Magic bytes ASCII string ‘MAJYO’

details.dc:description: XLD4 is a raster graphics format, sometimes known as Q4 file, associated with PC-98 a lineup of 16 and 32 bit computers manufactured by NEC in Japan. Each image consists of two separate files, one with a q4 extension and another with a q4d extension. The q4 file contains the bitmap image and the q4d the text description. In PRONOM these have been given two separate PUIDs.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Aldus FreeHand Drawing Version 1
signature.note: BOF: MAC File Type Code 'acf3'

details.dc:description: FreeHand, created by Altsys Corporation in 1988 and licensed to Aldus Corporation, is a discontinued vector graphic editor for Windows and Mac. Uses include professional illustration, desktop publishing and web content. FreeHand versions 1 though to 4 were released by Aldus, later versions were developed by Macromedia. In 2005 Adobe Systems acquired Macromedia but FreeHand development has been discontinued. The first two versions were released only for Mac OS and have no official extensions.

signature.name: PDF Portfolio 1.7
signature.note: BOF: %PDF-1.7 followed by '/Collection ' and '<</CI<<'. EOF (offset up to 1024 bytes): '%%EOFF(.|F.|F..|F..)'

details.dc:description:
PDF Portfolio files are PDFs using a feature added to the PDF specification in version 1.7 called "Collections". Collections offer a way to embed file attachments that are related in structure or content, as well as information that a reader application should use to determine how to present these files. A simple metadata schema can also be defined for the collection, allowing metadata to be provided for each item in the collection. Additionally, folder structure can be provided for the collection items, allowing reader applications to present the attachments with a tree-view. This makes the PDF Portfolio a convenient format to export mailboxes as mail folder structure can be preserved, along with standard email metadata such as "To", "From" and "Subject" fields.
PDF Portfolio files can specify a "default view", which is a file in the collection that a reader application should display when opening the Portfolio.
details.dc:creator: Adobe Systems Incorporated

record_metadata.dc:creator: Preservica / Preservica

signature.name: Lotus 1-2-3 Worksheet Version 97
signature.note: Section Record Type = 0, record length dec 26 = 1A; file format version number = hex 03100400

details.dc:description:
Lotus 1-2-3 Workbook is a spreadsheet program produced by the Lotus Software Group (later acquired by IBM). The original release was in 1983 and it has been discontinued since 2013.
The original 1-2-3 files have .wks extensions. Version 2.0 originally used a .wk1 extension but this was changed quickly to .wk2 and after this the number in the extension corrolates with the version number. Some later versions have the extension .123

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

details.dc:description: Comic Book Archive (or comic book reader) files are zipped/compressed folders containing a number image files (although folders may be used to group images), for the purpose of the sequential viewing of these images, usually for comic books. They use a naming system which allows them to be displayed in order when used with a comic book reader, such as CD display. Comic book archive files are not a distinct file format; only the file extension differentiates them from the compressed file type they use. Comic book archive files use the following compression: .cb7 (7z), .cba (ACE), .cbr (RAR), .cbt (TAR), .cbz ( ZIP).

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Ableton Live Set
signature.note: BOF magic bytes: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>.<Ableton MajorVersion EOF magic bytes: </LiveSet>.</Ableton>

details.dc:description: Ableton Live Set (.als) files are created by Ableton Live, audio production software for Mac or Windows, which enables the recording and layout of live music sets. As of release 8.2.1, .als files appear to consist of a Gzipped XML file, but with the .als extension. Earlier version of .als files may vary. Please contact the PRONOM team if you are able to assist with identification of other versions.
details.dc:creator: Ableton

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: multiArtist File (.mg1)
signature.note: BOF: 'MGH' then 0x01 (SOH or start of header) then 0x01

signature.name: multiArtist File (.mg2)
signature.note: BOF: 'MGH' then 0x01 (SOH or start of header) then 0x02

signature.name: multiArtist File (.mg4)
signature.note: BOF: 'MGH' then 0x01 (SOH or start of header) then 0x04

signature.name: multiArtist File (.mg8)
signature.note: BOF: 'MGH' then 0x01 (SOH or start of header) then 0x08

details.dc:description: multiArtist is a PC (Windows) program for creating MultiGigaScreen graphics for the ZX Spectrum. It is likely that the four known file extensions (.mg1, .mg2, .mg4 and .mg8) relate to the attribute blocks (8x1, 8x2, 8x4, 8x8) in a given file.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: MAKIchan Graphics (.mki - "MAKI01A " Signature)
signature.note: BOF: 'MAKI01A' then 0x20 (space). The first of the two known signatures for .mki files associated with the MAKIchan Graphics file format.

signature.name: MAKIchan Graphics (.mki - "MAKI01B " Signature)
signature.note: BOF: 'MAKI01B' then 0x20 (space). The second of the two known signatures for .mki files associated with the MAKIchan Graphics file format.

signature.name: MAKIchan Graphics (.mag/.max "MAKI02 " Signature)
signature.note: BOF: 'MAKI02' then 0x20 (space). Signature for both .mag and .max files associatd with the MAKIchan Graphics file format.

details.dc:description: MAKIchan is a family of raster image file formats developed in the early 1990s by Woody-Rinn, a Japanese software developer. The first specificaiton, MAKI v1, refers and relates to .mki files. The second specificaiton, MAKI v2, is for .mag and .max files, with the latter supporting higher resolutions, as well as the native YJK colour model for MSX2 computers.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: MIG Graphics File
signature.note: BOF: 'MSXMIG'

details.dc:description: MIG is a graphics (raster image) file format for the MSX system, created by Louthrax. It is related to the MIF file, improving on its ability to browse large, interlaced MSX2 pictures. It utlises TeamBomba's decompression tool BitBuster.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Multi Palette Picture File

format.name: TEI P4 XML - Single Text File

signature.name: TEI P4 XML - Single Text
signature.note: BOF:'<?xml version=("OR')1.0("OR')' followed by a gap between 0-512 bytes followed by 'TEI.2'

details.dc:description:
The Text Encoding Initiative Guidelines provide a methodology for encoding textual content for a wide variety of academic and publishing purposes and repurposes. P4 is serialised as XML.
Conceptually, TEI is a sibling of HTML which focuses on textual semantics rather than display.
The ‘ODD’ file extension is used when TEI is being used as a literate programming language for XML schemas, modern TEI guidelines are written in this form of the language, HTML, RNG, RNC and DTD files are then generated from the TEI.
Note that TEI permits customisations and some may mean that the file no longer matches the attached signatures. This is especially the case where TEI is fragmented, embedded within other XML or when other XML namespaces are used.
Information on how to convert TEI P4 to TEI P5 can be found at https://www.tei-c.org/Vault/P4/migrate.html and a script at https://www.tei-c.org/Vault/P4/p4top5.xsl Such automated conversion is not guaranteed to be lossless, particularly when the TEI has been customised.
P4 differs from the proceeding P3 version by being in XML rather than in SGML

record_metadata.dc:creator: Victoria University of Wellington / Victoria University of Wellington

signature.name: TEI P4 XML - Corpus
signature.note: BOF:'<?xml version=("OR')1.0("OR')' followed by a gap between 0-512 bytes followed by 'teiCorpus.2'

details.dc:description:
The Text Encoding Initiative Guidelines provide a methodology for encoding textual content for a wide variety of academic and publishing purposes and repurposes. P4 is serialised as XML. Conceptually, TEI is a sibling of HTML which focuses on textual semantics rather than display.
Note that TEI permits customisations and some may mean that the file no longer matches the attached signatures. This is especially the case where TEI is fragmented, embedded within other XML or when other XML namespaces are used.
Information on how to convert TEI P4 to TEI P5 can be found at https://www.tei-c.org/Vault/P4/migrate.html and a script at https://www.tei-c.org/Vault/P4/p4top5.xsl Such automated conversion is not guaranteed to be lossless, particularly when the TEI has been customised.
P4 differs from the proceeding P3 version by being in XML rather than in SGML

record_metadata.dc:creator: Victoria University of Wellington / Victoria University of Wellington

signature.name: TEI P5 XML - Single Text
signature.note: BOF:'<?xml version=("OR')1.0("OR')' followed by a gap between 0-512 bytes followed by 'TEI' followed by a gap between 0-512 bytes followed by 'http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0'

details.dc:description:
The Text Encoding Initiative Guidelines (TEI) provide a methodology for encoding textual content for a wide variety of academic and publishing purposes and repurposes. TEI P5 is serialised as XML.
Conceptually, TEI is a sibling of HTML which focuses on textual semantics rather than display.
The ‘ODD’ file extension is used when TEI is being used as a literate programming language for XML schemas, modern TEI guidelines are written in this form of the language, HTML, RNG, RNC and DTD files are then generated from the TEI.
Note that TEI permits customisations and some may mean that the file no longer matches the signatures. This is especially the case where TEI is fragmented, embedded within other XML or when other XML namespaces are used.
Customisation is primarily done via TEI-supplied tools, formerly PizzaChef https://tei-c.org/Vault/P4/pizza.html and now Roma https://roma2.tei-c.org/
P5 differs from the preceding P4 version, amongst other things, using the then-new xml:lang and xml:id tags.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Victoria University of Wellington / Victoria University of Wellington

signature.name: TEI P5 XML - Corpus
signature.note: BOF:'<?xml version=("OR')1.0("OR')' followed by a gap between 0-512 bytes followed by 'teiCorpus' followed by a gap between 0-512 bytes followed by 'http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0'

details.dc:description:
The Text Encoding Initiative Guidelines provide a methodology for encoding textual content for a wide variety of academic and publishing purposes and repurposes. P5 is based on XML.
Conceptually, TEI is a sibling of HTML which focuses on textual semantics rather than display.
Note that TEI permits customisations and some may mean that the file no longer matches the attached signatures. This is especially the case where TEI is fragmented, embedded within other XML or when other XML namespaces are used.
TEI customisation is primarily done via TEI-supplied tools, formerly PizzaChef https://tei-c.org/Vault/P4/pizza.html and now Roma https://roma2.tei-c.org/
P5 differs from the preceding P4 version, amongst other things, using the then-new xml:lang and xml:id tags.

signature.name: Unisig
signature.note: BOF: 0xDCDC0D0A1A0A00

details.dc:description: Unisig is a uniform signature scheme for binary file formats and network protocols created by Lassi Kortela and John Cowan. It is intended as a building block for other format vendors to provide a reliable mechanism for file format identification. Unisig itself doesn't have a specific extension or media type - it is intended that format vendors using Unisig will provide their own.

signature.name: HyperCard Stack
signature.note: BOF, offset 4: 'STAK' 0xFFFFFFFF

details.dc:description: HyperCard Stack is a legacy file format used with the HyperCard application software. HyperCard was developed by Bill Atkinson for use on Apple Macintosh and Apple IIGS computers and was first released by Apple in 1987. Atkinson created HyperCard as a tool that non-programmers could use to write their own computer applications. The HyperCard program stored information in documents referred to as stacks. Each HyperCard stack consisted of related cards, which could contain text, images, interactive elements, and sound. individual cards within the stack to each other and that played various sounds as the user clicked them. The structure of HyperCard was based conceptually on physical card-filing systems, like Rolodex, or a flat-file database that used hyperlinks as navigation. HyperCard Stacks typically lack a format extension.

signature.note: BOF (Offset 2):'IIXPR'{1}'P'.

details.dc:description: QuarkXPress is desktop publishing software for creating and editing page layouts that can be run on Mac and Windows operating systems. It was first released in 1987. It can be used to creating a variety of layouts, from single-page flyers to multi-media projects required for magazines, newspapers and catalogues. Versions 1-3 were available on Macintosh only, from version 3.1 a common signature is used.
details.dc:creator: Quark, Inc

signature.name: CompuServe RLE
signature.note: BOF: Magic bytes: '.GH or .GM'

details.dc:description: CompuServe RLE is a type of run-length encoding graphics monochrome file format, introduced by CompuServe in the 1980s to be used by the CompuServe on-line service. It is the predecessor of CompuServe's GIF file format that supported colour and was invented by Steve Wilhite. The image dimensions are either Medium (128x96) and High (256x192) resolution RLE- compressed files. Files consist entirely of ASCII characters, though some are control characters.
details.dc:creator: Compuserve Incorporated

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Raster Matrix Format
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic bytes: 'RSW.'

details.dc:description: Raster Matrix Format (RMF) is a simple tiled raster format used in the Geographical Information System (GIS) “Integration” and “Panorama” GIS. There are two varieties of RMF called MTW and RSW and this record describes the RSW type. RSW can store 8-bit data and is a general purpose raster that supports single channel colormapped or three channel RGB images. Simple georeferencing can be provided with this image type.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: NeoDesk Icon File
signature.note: BOF:'.NIC' followed by 0x03 (end of text) followed by 0x00 (null) followed by ';NeoDesk Icon File format, Copyright ½ 1990 Gribnif Software'

pattern.regex: (?s)\A\.NIC\x03\x00;NeoDesk Icon File format, Copyright \xbd 1990 Gribnif Software

details.dc:description: NeoDisk icon file format is associated with the NeoDesk graphical environment, developed by Gribnif Software, for the Atari ST family of computers. Three versions of NeoDesk icon files exist. This is the third version which is identified by the signature that begins with ASCII '.NIC'.

First released in 1991, Visual Basic was declared legacy in 2008. It provided a GUI which allowed users to modify code by dragging and dropping objects and defining their behaviour and appearance.

details.dc:description: NeoDisk icon file format is associated with the NeoDesk graphical environment, developed by Gribnif Software, for the Atari ST family of computers. Three versions of NeoDesk icon files exist. The first and the second and uncompressed and have no discernible signature. The first verison consists of 9 icons (232 bytes each) for a total file size of 2088 bytes. The second version consists of any number of icons (244 bytes each) with the total file size a multiple of 244. These can currently be identified by extension only using DROID.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Daisy-Dot Font (Version I and II)
signature.note: BOF:'DAISY-DOT NLQ FONT'

details.dc:description: Daisy-Dot is a text processing program written by Roy Goldman for the Atari line of computers enabling dot-matrix printers to utilise near letter quality (NLQ) printing technology. Three versions of Daisy-Dot were released between 1987 and 1990. A number of Daisy-Dot font files are pre-packaged with the text processor while others can be user-generated using the Daisy-Dot font editor. Daisy-Dot I and II fonts can be identified by the ASCII signature 'DAISY-DOT NLQ FONT'.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.note: BOF:'3' followed by 0x9B

Three versions of Daisy-Dot were released between 1987 and 1990. A number of Daisy-Dot font files are pre-packaged with the text processor while others can be user-generated using the Daisy-Dot font editor. Daisy-Dot I and II fonts can be identified by the ASCII signature '3' followed by 0x9B.

signature.name: Visual Basics MAK File
signature.note: Magic bytes EOF range 0-55: ProjWinSize=[7-15]..ProjWinShow=[1-3]..IconForm="Form

details.dc:description: MAK (make) files are project files created by Microsoft Visual Basic version 3 and earlier. They store information including references to forms, source code and module files. MAK files were replaced with VBP files in Visual Basics 4 onwards.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Canadian Centre for Architecture / The Canadian Centre for Architecture

details.dc:description: A Mat-file stores data in binary form. You can read and write Mat-files using MATLAB. Level 4 MAT files are compatible with MATLAB versions up to Version 4.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: NetWare Loadable Module
signature.note: BOF:'NetWare Loadable Module' followed by 0x1A followed by 0x04

details.dc:description: A NetWare Loadable Module (NLM) is a loadable kernel module (a binary code module) that can be loaded into Novell's NetWare operating system. NLMs can implement hardware drivers, server functions (e.g. clustering), applications (e.g. GroupWise), system libraries or utilities.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Surprise! Adlib Tracker v2.0
signature.note: BOF: 'Magic Bytes'; SAdT

details.dc:description: Surprise! Adlib Tracker v2.0 is a version of Surprise! Adlib tracker for the MS-DOS operating system. AdLib tracker is a 9-channel FM tracker for the OPL2-compatible chips found on most sound cards. It is a tool for creating audio with FM-synthesis and uses non-standard Volume Slide procedure in replay routine.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Septentrio Binary Format
signature.note: BOF: offset 0-3000; Magic bytes '$@{460-3000}PolaRxS_PRO'

details.dc:description: Septentrio Binary Format (SBF) is the binary output format of Septentrio receivers, with data are arranged in binary blocks referred to as SBF blocks. Each block consists of a sequence of numeric or alphanumeric fields of different types and sizes. The total block size is always a multiple of 4 bytes. This format is used in conjunction with the Septentrio PolaRxS PRO GNSS receiver, that performs over multiple frequencies and constellations. It is used for ionospheric monitoring and space weather observations.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: DNA Sequence Chromatogram File
signature.note: BOF; offset: 0-3; Magic Bytes: '.scf'

details.dc:description:
DNA Sequence Chromatogram File format refers to Chromatogram files, which have .scf as their file extension. They are associated with the DNA Baser Sequence Aligner software and are used to store data from DNA sequencing instruments.
The files contain the data for a single reading and includes: its trace sample points, its called sequence, the positions of the bases relative to the trace sample points, and numerical estimates of the accuracy of each base. The SCF format was designed to be easily compressed (using programs like WinRar or WinZip). This allows companies to store large amounts of chromatogram files.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Standard Data Format
signature.note: Magic bytes, BOF, offset 0: G0 Magic bytes: 0x0D (Carriage Return) followed by 0x0A (Line Feed) followed by 0x1A (Substitute)

details.dc:description: Standard Data Format (SDF) files are commonly used to transfer data between different programs. SDF files are formatted ASCII text files, in which fields are delimited with a particular character (usually a space), and each record ends with a carriage return and/or line feed.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: Starlink Data Format
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: SDS

details.dc:description: Starlink Data Format (SDF) was developed for Starlink project which was set up in late 1980s to provide data reduction software and facilities to United Kingdom astronomers. The format has an extention .sdf and is the binary format that stores structures of data using Hierarchical Data System (HDS) library, that implements the SDF format, providing the hierarchical structuting with the ability to read and write SDF format. In mid-1980s a standard for writing information collected accompaining the volumetric data astronomy, (e.g. sky coordinations, what telescope took the measurements, errors, and other directly related measurements) was created, titled as the N-Dimensional Data Format (NDF). NDF serves as a data model, organasing and storing the bulk data collected in the form of N-dimensional arrays of numbers. The NDF format is based on the Hierarchical Data System (HDS) and is extensible; not only does it provide a comprehensive set of standard ancillary items to describe the data, it can also be extended indefinitely to handle additional user-defined information of any type. Prior to mid1980s, the most significant pre-NDF format used by a major data analysis package was called FIGARO, developed at the Anglo-Australian Observatory but was eventually was converted to use NDF.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Cyber Paint Sequence
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic bytes: þÛ..

details.dc:description: Cyber Paint Sequence is an animated raster graphics format associated with the Cyber Paint application created by Jim Kent for Atari ST computers. The aplication Cyber Paint was used with 2D animation program that brought together a wide variety of animation and paint functionality and the delta-compressed animation format developed for CAD-3D. Cyber Paint was one of the first consumer program that enabled the user to paint across time in a compressed digital video format. The programme was based on its predecessor Flicker, with Cyber Paint Sequence format being able to handle hundreds of frames rather than ten or twelve only.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: SelF-eXtracting LHA/LZH Compressed File
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 3370 - 3410; Magic bytes: C64/C128 SELF EXTRACTING LHARCHIVE

details.dc:description: SelF-eXtracting LHA/LZH compressed files is an archive format for the Commodore 64 and 128 consisting of files compressed in the LHA format and appended to a program to extract them, so that the archive and its extractor is self-contained and no other program needs to be downloaded or installed in order to extract the archive. It is a sucessor of SDA format with an addition of the extractor is cross-compatible between both Commodore platforms (C-64 and C-128).

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Beam Software SIFF File
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: SIFF

details.dc:description:
A Beam Software SIFF file is an audio file used by a Beam Software video game. Beam Software is an Australian video game developer that was founded in 1978 and acquired by Krome Studios in 2006, at which point Beam was renamed Krome Studios Melbourne. In the 1990s, Beam produced a handful of games that use their proprietary SIFF file format. The file contains music, sound effects, or dialogue played within a game. The files cannot be played by most popular media players but can be converted to a standard audio format.
The SIFF file format can be used to create files that contain both audio and video or just audio. When a SIFF format file contains both audio and video, it is saved with the .vb extension rather then .son extension.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Sample Vision Audio File Format
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: SOUND SAMPLE DATA

details.dc:description: The SampleVision format is native to the Turtle Beach SampleVision program. The format supports mono 16-bit audio and loop points.The Format was developed for use with the SampleVision software program, which was designed to send and receive samples via the MIDI interface on a PC. It consists of a variable-length header followed by a contiguous block of binary data representing the sound samples.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: SpritePad Image Format
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: SPD

details.dc:description: SpritePad is a free cross-development tool for designing sprite images and animations for the Commodore 64 computer. It allows the user to freehand painting or import and convert any existing bitmap image into a C64 compatible sprite or tile set using various tile sizes from 1 x 1 up to 8x8 sprites (64 different sizes). SpritePad has began development in 2003.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: AutoDesk Indexed Point Cloud
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: PCG

details.dc:description: PCG files are file formats developed by Autodesk to specifically meet the demands of their software suite. They are indexed point cloud data generated using AutoDesk Revit mainly from PTS files. Support for PCG was removed in favor of newer RCP/RCS formats. Autodesk products, however, are often able to convert some open formats, such as PTS into PCG files. PCG is a cloud format that is able to work to manipulate scans and stitch them together into a single cloud, which can then be exported as a standalone file. It can be used in conjunction with Leica Cyclone point cloud processing software which is a family of software modules that provides set of work process options for 3D laser scanning projects in engineering, surveying, construction and related applications.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

format.name: ERDAS Imagine Large Raster Spill File

signature.name: ERDAS Imagine Large Raster Spill File
signature.note: Magic bytes: ERDAS_IMG_EXTERNAL_RASTER

details.dc:description: .ige files are generated by ERDAS Imagine software, when the RRD file exceeds 2GB (or now 4GB, as suggested by some sources) in size. For these larger projects, two extra files are generated: .img files, and these ige files, which stores the actual image data.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

details.dc:description:
The ASiC-E container is a ZIP archive file containing set of data objects and associated signatures. It is designed to associate an advanced electronic signature with any type of data. It operates with signature and time-stamp token formats XAdES, CAdES, timestamp RFC 3161.
The container has an internal structure including a root folder for all the container content possibly including folders reflecting the content structure and a META-INF folder, in the root folder, for metadata about the content, including associated signatures.
The integrity of the data is guaranteed by the electronic signature when present or should be provided externally if only a time-stamp token is applied to the data. Privacy can be guaranteed through the use of ZIP encryption features or externally. External integrity and privacy protection can be obtained e.g. through the use of SSL/TLS or S/MIME.
ASiC-E container contains multiple data objects, each object may be signed by one or more signature carried in the container.

record_metadata.dc:description: This format can be identified via a container signature in DROID version 6 or later. The PRONOM database cannot currently represent container signatures.

details.dc:description: reStructuredText files are in effect plain text documents, formatted with a lightweight markup language, to produce more easily readable documents such as pdf. Rst files are used primarily by members of the Python programming community to create technical documentation for Python libraries. They are generated by running Docutils (https://docutils.sourceforge.io/), an open source text processing system which can turn plain text files, into useful formats, within Python.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Norwegian Unix Users Group / Norwegian Unix Users Group

signature.name: ColdFusion Markup Language
signature.note: BOF: magic bytes: <cf (offset 0-100) EOF: magic bytes: cf{5-100}> (offset 0-5)

details.dc:description: ColdFusion Markup Language (CFML) is a scripting language used for writing web pages and dynamic PC applications. It was created in 1995 by corporation Allaire, but was acquired by Adobe in 2005. ColdFusion Markup Language tags have a similar format to html tags, (for example, they are enclosed in angle brackets.) These are text based files, which can be opened by any text editor, such as Notepad.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: ISDOC Information System Document (Generic)
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 16-300; Magic bytes: 'isdoc.cz'

details.dc:description: ISDOC is a type of Extensible Markup Language (XML) file format specific for transfer of financial documents. It allows paperless exchanging of invoices and other documents, processing and portability among companies, public administration authorities and individuals. It was defined by “A Working group for Electronic Standards of data exchanging” in ICT Union (formerly SPIS). The “Declaration on common approach in the area of electronic invoicing in the Czech Republic” was signed on 16th October 2008. It represents a Czech customization of UBL standard https://www.iso.org/standard/66370.html. ISDOC file enables enveloped signatures including advanced IETF/W3C XML digital signatures conforming to the ETSI XAdES specification. This signiture records a general ISDOC file format, however there are several versions of this format which can be found here: http://www.isdoc.cz/index.php?id=1316.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives of the Czech Republic / The National Archives of the Czech Republic

signature.name: ISDOCX Information System Document (Generic)
signature.note: BOF; Offset:0; Magic bytes: 'PK' & EOF; Offset:12-1000; Magic bytes: '.isdoc'

details.dc:description:
ISDOCX is a type of ZIP container file for transferring ISDOC documents and other material. Then content of this file format varies, but it should always contain ISDOC file format, and usually does contain a Portable Document Format (PDF). This signiture records a general ISDOCX file format, however there are several versions of this format which can be found here: http://www.isdoc.cz/index.php?id=1316. Versions 6.0.1 must also contain 'manifest.xml' namespace file, this signiture records all versions prior to 6.0.1 without a 'manifest.xml' namespace file.
ISDOC format is a type of Extensible Markup Language (XML) file format specific for transfer of financial, as well as other documents. It allows paperless exchanging of invoices and other documents, processing and portability among companies, public administration authorities and individuals. It was defined by “A Working group for Electronic Standards of data exchanging” in ICT Union (formerly SPIS). The “Declaration on common approach in the area of electronic invoicing in the Czech Republic” was signed on 16th October 2008. It represents a Czech customization of UBL standard https://www.iso.org/standard/66370.html. ISDOC file enables enveloped signatures including advanced IETF/W3C XML digital signatures conforming to the ETSI XAdES specification.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives of the Czech Republic / The National Archives of the Czech Republic

signature.name: Bitstream Speedo Fonts
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 100-300; Magic bytes: 'Copyright 1989-1991 by Bitstream Inc. All rights reserved'

pattern.regex: (?s)\A.{100,300}Copyright 1989-1991 by Bitstream Inc\. All rights reserved\.

details.dc:description: The Speedo fonts are a type of scalable font, created by Bitstream, Inc. The font was widely used in the disk operating system (DOS) era of computers, but has since became obsolete and is not used by any current software. Speedo was used on Atari ST, Falcon, in the XyWrite word processor, and in very early versions of WordPerfect and Microsoft Windows. It was then replaced by more popular font types like Type 1 fonts. Before Speedo was considered obsolete it was supported by the X Window System through the speedo module, and most Linux distributions had a Speedo font package, but support was removed from X in the X11R7.0 release in 2005. Speedo fonts include large international character set (over six hundred characters) and they are able to adapt their "pixels", "points", "horiz", "vert", and "avgwidth" XLFD values to match whatever value is requested by the X server.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

details.dc:description: ISDOC is a type of Extensible Markup Language (XML) file format specific for transfer of financial documents. It allows paperless exchanging of invoices and other documents, processing and portability among companies, public administration authorities and individuals. It was defined by “A Working group for Electronic Standards of data exchanging” in ICT Union (formerly SPIS). The “Declaration on common approach in the area of electronic invoicing in the Czech Republic” was signed on 16th October 2008. It represents a Czech customization of UBL standard https://www.iso.org/standard/66370.html. ISDOC file enables enveloped signatures including advanced IETF/W3C XML digital signatures conforming to the ETSI XAdES specification. This signiture records the 6.0.1 version of ISDOC file format, developed in May 2014. More information about other versions can be found: http://www.isdoc.cz/index.php?id=1316.

signature.name: OrCAD Project File
signature.note: BOF:'(ExpressProject' followed by 0x20 (Space)

details.dc:description:
OrCAD, a proprietary software tool suite used primarily for electronic design automation (EDA). The software is used mainly by electronic design engineers and electronic technicians to create electronic schematics, perform mixed-signal simulation and electronic prints for manufacturing printed circuit boards. OrCAD was taken over by Cadence Design Systems in 1999 and was integrated with Cadence Allegro since 2005.
A OrCAD Project File (.OPJ) is a container for the OrCAD design file (.DSN). In addition, a project file also includes simulation profile and layout information.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Visual Basic Project File
signature.note: Magic bytes BOF (Offset 0): Type=Exe.. Magic bytes EOF (Offset 0): (MaxNumberOfThreads={1}..

details.dc:description: These are project files created by Visual Basic, a software development tool for Windows, which stored project information in a plain text format. The vbp files refer to other resources in the project, including forms (.FRM files) souce code files (.BAS files) and class module files (.CLS extension). Visual Basic software was replaced with Visual Basic.NET, which doesn’t generate .vbp files.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: Visual Basic Project Workspace File
signature.note: Magic bytes BOF, offset 0 - 36: frm Magic bytes EOF, offset 0: ..

details.dc:description: These are files created by Visual Basic, a software development tool for Windows. The files hold coordinate positions for each window in the visual programming environment, and are used to reload elements into their previous positions after a close/reopen. Visual Basic software has been replaced with Visual Basic.NET., which doesn’t generate .vbw files.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: Spectrum 512 Compressed and Smooshed
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'SP.'

details.dc:description:
Spectrum 512 was a computer paint program by Boris Tsikanovsky that enabled the creation of images with more than 16 simultaneous colors. It uses the Atari ST's rapid palette switching ability to expand the maximum number of colors to be displayed on-screen at once to 512 (up to 46 in each scan line). Spectrum 512 is a predecessor of Unispec.
This specific file format record details Spectrum 512 compressed formats. There are two varieties of compression in Spectrum 512 formats, first is Spectrum 512 Compressed and second Spectrum 512 Smooshed. Both of these formats have an identical file format signiture (magic bytes) and the only way to distinguish between these formats is by their extension. The Spectrum 512 Compressed format uses .spc and the Spectrum 512 Smooshed format uses .sps extension. Compression is via a modified run length encoding (RLE) scheme in both of these formats however, the files differ in in a compression methods depending on format type.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

details.dc:description:
Spectrum 512 was a computer paint program by Boris Tsikanovsky that enabled the creation of images with more than 16 simultaneous colors. It uses the Atari ST's rapid palette switching ability to expand the maximum number of colors to be displayed on-screen at once to 512 (up to 46 in each scan line). Spectrum 512 is a predecessor of Unispec.
This specific file format record details Spectrum 512 uncompressed formats. There are two varieties of uncompression in Spectrum 512 formats, first is Spectrum 512 Uncompressed and second Spectrum 512 Uncompressed Enhanced. Both of these formats have an unidentifiable file format signiture (magic bytes) and have the same extension. In the uncompressed files, the first 160 bytes are usually set to zero (except in the "Enhanced" variant). Following that are 31840 bytes of image data (160 for each row). Following that are 19104 bytes of palette data. The total file size is 51104 bytes. The Spectrum 512 Uncompressed Enhanced format extends the palette further, to 5 bits per color channel.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Spectrum 512 Extended v1
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'SPX.'

details.dc:description:
Spectrum 512 was a computer paint program by Boris Tsikanovsky that enabled the creation of images with more than 16 simultaneous colors. It uses the Atari ST's rapid palette switching ability to expand the maximum number of colors to be displayed on-screen at once to 512 (up to 46 in each scan line). Spectrum 512 is a predecessor of Unispec.
Spectrum 512 Extended (spx) files are extended Spectrum files with more than 200 lines in the picture, designed by Gizmo of Electronic Images. With a SPX creator like SPXCRT14.PRG multiple spectrum pictures can be attached to become one big .SPX file. There are two known versions of the format. This record details Version 1, both versions support larger pictures in Spectrum 512.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Spectrum 512 Extended v2
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'SPX.'

details.dc:description:
Spectrum 512 was a computer paint program by Boris Tsikanovsky that enabled the creation of images with more than 16 simultaneous colors. It uses the Atari ST's rapid palette switching ability to expand the maximum number of colors to be displayed on-screen at once to 512 (up to 46 in each scan line). Spectrum 512 is a predecessor of Unispec.
Spectrum 512 Extended (spx) files are extended Spectrum files with more than 200 lines in the picture, designed by Gizmo of Electronic Images. With a SPX creator like SPXCRT14.PRG multiple spectrum pictures can be attached to become one big .SPX file. There are two known versions of the format. This record details Version 2, files of this format (as compared to Version 1) can be packed as a whole, including the header, with either Ice 2.10 or Atomik 3.5. Both versions support larger pictures in Spectrum 512.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: SPY (SPYne Containers)
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 0xA70220A0E5A90A8D

details.dc:description: SPYne containers were created by John Lannetta c1995 and are found in Compuserve's CBM applications forum and in COMP.BINARIES.CBM newsgroup. The format is self-extracting and does not employ any compression. The word "SPYNE" does not represent any acronym, but is meant to represent a "spine", with files linked together like a human spine.
details.dc:creator: Compuserve Incorporated

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Envision Publisher file
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'EnVision Publisher'

details.dc:description:
EVP files are document files created by using EnVision Publisher and start with the ASCII characters EnVision Publisher DTP document file.
EnVision Publisher was published by Software Vision in 1993, as a MS-DOS based (and later Windows 3.1) word processing program. At the time, it was an advanced desktop publishing program for Windows, with the ability to create publishing projects such as newsletters, flyers, brochures, business cards, and other printed material. The software's selling point was its low cost and ease of use of some advanced featured compared to its competitiors at the time. This desktop publishing program features a graphical WYSIWYG (What You See Is What You Get) interface, horizontal and vertical toolbars and rulers, templates for fliers and newsletters, 4 fonts, spell checker, style sheets, line, graphic, fill options, kerning, line justification, text rotation and color, cut, copy, paste, PCX and text import, zoom, page insert, clear, and delete, on-line help, and more.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

SVF files are font files utilized by EnVision Publisher.

At the time, it was an advanced desktop publishing program for Windows, with the ability to create publishing projects such as newsletters, flyers, brochures, business cards, and other printed material. The software's selling point was its low cost and ease of use of some advanced featured compared to its competitiors at the time. This desktop publishing program features a graphical WYSIWYG (What You See Is What You Get) interface, horizontal and vertical toolbars and rulers, templates for fliers and newsletters, 4 fonts, spell checker, style sheets, line, graphic, fill options, kerning, line justification, text rotation and color, cut, copy, paste, PCX and text import, zoom, page insert, clear, and delete, on-line help, and more.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Vim SWAP file
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'b0VIM'

details.dc:description:
Vim SWAP file is a temporary file created by the open source Vim text editor, when editing a file. The file's name typically begins with ".", and ends with ".swp". The file is normally deleted when editing is complete, but may be left behind in the event of a crash or other abnormal termination. Its main purpose is to periodically record unsaved changes made to the file. It also serves as a lock file. The file format is undocumented, and not necessarily portable.
Vim is free and open-source, screen-based text editor program for Unix, released to the public in 1991. Vim was designed for use both from a command-line interface and as a standalone application in a graphical user interface.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: SXG (ZX Spectrum) Graphic File
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: '.SXG.'

details.dc:description: SXG is a graphics format for the ZX Spectrum. SXG stands for "Speccy eXtended Graphic". Speccy is another name Spectrum is commonly known by its fan following. The ZX Spectrum is an 8-bit personal home computer developed by Sinclair Research, pioneered by Clive Sinclair. It was first released in the United Kingdom on 23 April 1982 and went on to become Britain's best-selling microcomputer. Games comprised the majority of commercial ZX Spectrum software. The SXG format was mostly used for graphics in early computer games on ZX Spectrum microcomputers.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: ADRIFT Text Adventure File
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: '<B?Éj‡ÂÏ'

details.dc:description:
ADRIFT Text Adventure File is an Interactive Fiction games file, produced by Campbell Wild's ADRIFT (Adventure Developer & Runner - Interactive Fiction Toolkit).
ADRIFT was created for Miscrosoft Windows and runs under Windows 95, 98, and NT. It does not require extensive programming knowledge, as it provides a series of dialog boxes which can be filled-out with descriptions and properties of each location, object and character. It is not based on the traditional model of compiled source and interpreted binary files but instead, a game exists only as a single binary file which is created by the Generator (a series of specialised editors) and read by the Runner. Both components use a Windows-style graphical interface, and are largely mouse-driven.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: TurboCalc Document
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: '...TURBOCALC'

details.dc:description: TurboCalc Document is a spreadsheet application developed by Gregory R. Schmalhofer and published by Stefan Ossowski's Schatztruhe (better known as Aminet) for the Commodore 64 used on Amiga operating system. The system is very similar to Microsoft Excel. There were several vesions of TurboCalc published in the years of 1980 - 1999.
details.dc:creator: Compuserve Incorporated

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: TheDraw Save File
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: '.TheDraw Save File'

details.dc:description:
TheDraw Save File (also known as TheDraw format, TheDraw Data File, or TheDraw Setup Save) is a layered character graphics format native to TheDraw, a character graphics editor for MS-DOS.
TheDraw is a text editor for MS-DOS to create ANSI and animations as well as ASCII art. The editor creates or modifies files in ANSI format and text documents, which use the graphical characters of the IBM ASCII code pages, as they are no longer supported by Microsoft Windows. The first version of the editor was developed in 1986 by Ian E. Davis of TheSoft Programming Services. The last public version of the editor was version 4.63, which was released in October 1993.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: COKE format (Atari Falcon)
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'COKE Format.'

details.dc:description:
COKE Format is a simple uncompressed raster image format associated with Atari Falcon computers.
The Atari Falcon030 (usually shortened to Atari Falcon), released in 1992, was the final personal computer product from Atari Corporation. A high-end model of the Atari ST line, the machine is based on a Motorola 68030 CPU and a Motorola 56000 digital signal processor, a feature which distinguishes it from most other microcomputers of the era. It included a VIDEL programmable graphics system which greatly improved graphics capabilities.

details.dc:description: Tgif (pronounced t-g-i-f) is an Xlib-based interactive 2-D drawing tool (using vector graphics) under X11 on Linux and most UNIX platforms (including Mac OS X and cygwin on Windows). It was developed since 1990 and is free software released under the QPL license.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Taquart Interlace Picture
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'TIP.'

details.dc:description:
Taquart Interlace Picture is a graphics format developed for ATARI 400, 800, 130 XE and XL, all part of Atari 8-bit family.
The Atari 8-bit family is a series of 8-bit home computers introduced by Atari, Inc. in 1979 as the Atari 400 and Atari 800 and manufactured until 1992. All of the machines in the family are technically similar and differ primarily in packaging. They are based on the MOS Technology 6502 CPU running at 1.79 MHz, and were the first home computers designed with custom coprocessor chips.

signature.name: ESRI ArcInfo Coverage Annotation File
signature.note: Magic bytes, Absolute from beginning of file: ..'ÿÿÿ.½

details.dc:description: Files which form part of an ArcInfo Coverage, which is a data model whose purpose is to store georelational data such as spatial location and descriptive data. Each ArcInfo Coverage resides in an ArcInfo workspace, a directory which contains two or more folders. These packages are generated using ArcGIS software, produced by Esri (https://www.esri.com/en-us/arcgis/about-arcgis/overview.) Files with the .txt extension contain text strings describing a geographic feature, formatted in user defined tables.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: ASEG-GDF2 Description file
signature.note: BOF, absolute zero, magic bytes: PROJGDA EOF, absolute zero, magic bytes: Export

details.dc:description: ASEG-GDF2 (Australian Society of Exploration Geophysicists General Data Format Revision 2) is a data standard for the exchange and archive of geophysical data. Its primary purpose is to provide a consistent and self-documenting method for exchanging and archiving geophysical data between organisations with different hardware and software systems. For data to comply with the standard, it must be stored as a set of related ASCII files, which must include the following four filetypes as a minimum: File1.DAT, survey.DES, survey.DFN and survey.MET.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: ASEG-GDF2- Data definition file
signature.note: BOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes: DEFN EOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes: Export ..

details.dc:description: ASEG-GDF2 (Australian Society of Exploration Geophysicists General Data Format Revision 2) is a data standard for the exchange and archive of geophysical data. Its primary purpose is to provide a consistent and self-documenting method for exchanging and archiving geophysical data between organisations with different hardware and software systems. For data to comply with the standard, it must be stored as a set of related ASCII files, which must include the following four filetypes as a minimum: File1.DAT, survey.DES, survey.DFN and survey.MET. The .dfn files enable the writing of code to enable to recovery of the geophysical data fields and their associated formats.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: ESRI ArcInfo .dat File (external)
signature.note: BOF, offset 0, magic bytes: ../ EOF, offset 0-100, magic bytes,: .adf

details.dc:description: Files which comprise part of an ArcInfo Coverage, which is a data model whose purpose is to store georelational data such as spatial location and descriptive data. Each ArcInfo Coverage resides in an ArcInfo workspace, a directory which contains two or more folders. These packages are generated using ArcGIS software, produced by Esri (https://www.esri.com/en-us/arcgis/about-arcgis/overview.) An ArcInfo coverage dataset typically has two types of .dat file: internal, which store the actual data table, and external, which contains a relative path to the data table. External .dat files follow a unique naming pattern: arcXXXX.dat, where XXXX is incrementally increasing number starting from 0000, e.g. arc0000.dat, arc0001.dat. The .dat files always come in pair with a NIT file and are both stored in an INFO directory at the root.

signature.name: ESRI ArcInfo Grid .nit File
signature.note: BOF, offset 16: magic bytes .. ÿÿ….

details.dc:description: Files which comprise part of an ArcInfo Grid, a raster data model storing information in a matrix of cells, with values representing a coordinate, and sometimes linked to an attribute table. ArcInfo Grid models are generated using ArcGIS software, produced by Esri (https://www.esri.com/en-us/arcgis/about-arcgis/overview.) Nit files follow a consistent naming pattern: arcXXXX.nit, where XXXX is an incrementally increasing number starting from 0000, e.g, arc000.nit, arc0001.nit, arc0002.nit. Nit files are always stored in an /info/ directory at the root. They are associated with .dat and .adf files, and their function is to store file structure and field definition information of the grid.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

details.dc:description: Stata .do command files are optional text files used with in Stata, a research data analysis and statistical software package. Stata users can compile commands for Stata to run into a .do file, rather than typing them via the keyboard. This means commands do not have to be typed over and over again, and sets of commands can be reproduced at a later date. Such files are called .do files because the command that causes them to be executed is ‘do’. These files can be generated using a standard text editor, or the do-file editor which is built into Stata.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Yale University Library / Yale University Library

details.dc:description: Programme files for R, a programming language for statistical computing. The official R software is free, open source, and run on command line. Other companies have produced GUI software packages which are commercially available. R files contain code which can be executed within the R environment, including commands for creating objects such as functions and values.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Yale University Library / Yale University Library

details.dc:description: Files which comprise part of an ArcInfo Coverage, which is a data model whose purpose is to store georelational data such as spatial location and descriptive data. Each ArcInfo Coverage resides in an ArcInfo workspace, a directory which contains two or more folders. These packages are generated using ArcGIS software, produced by Esri (https://www.esri.com/en-us/arcgis/about-arcgis/overview.) An ArcInfo coverage dataset typically has two types of .dat file: internal, which store the actual data table, and external, which contains a relative path to the data table. These external files, which have extension .dat, follow a unique naming pattern: arcXXXX.dat, where XXXX is incrementally increasing number starting from 0000, e.g. arc0000.dat, arc0001.dat. The .dat files always come in pair with a NIT file and are both stored in an INFO directory at the root. Internal .dat files usually contain the byte sequence BOF, 000000.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: Type Library Type 1
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'SLTG' & EOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'TYPELIB'

details.dc:description:
This record describes Type Library Type 1 file format, files which mostly belong to Borland Type Library by Borland Software Corporation. A type library (.tlb) is a binary file that stores information about a COM or DCOM object's properties and methods in a form that is accessible to other applications at runtime. Type libraries provide a language-neutral mechanism for defining types such as interfaces, methods, classes, and other COM elements that are defined and used by a server and called on by a client. Type libraries are saved as binary files with a .tlb extension or can be contained within the binary file representing the server ( *.dll , *.ocx , *.exe , *.olb ).
Using a type library, an application or browser can determine which interfaces an object supports, and invoke an object's interface methods. This can occur even if the object and client applications were written in different programming languages. The COM/DCOM run-time environment can also use a type library to provide automatic cross-apartment, cross-process, and cross-machine marshaling for interfaces described in type libraries.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: TUNDRA
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: '.TUNDRA24'

details.dc:description: TUNDRA is a graphics format and is one of several systems for expressing text-mode graphics using text characters and control characters setting positions and colours. ANSI Art was the main system of this use, but a few others were invented during the Bulletin Board System (BBS) era. The ansilove (and Ansilove-C and ansilove.js) open-source software can display TUNDRA among other formats, by converting ANSI/ASCII art to PNG images.

details.dc:description:
EggPaint is a simple uncompressed raster image format with 16 bits/pixel (RGB 5-6-5 format) and an 8-byte header, used on Atari Falcon computers.
The Atari Falcon030 (usually shortened to Atari Falcon), released in 1992, was the final personal computer product from Atari Corporation. A high-end model of the Atari ST line, the machine is based on a Motorola 68030 CPU and a Motorola 56000 digital signal processor, a feature which distinguishes it from most other microcomputers of the era. It included a VIDEL programmable graphics system which greatly improved graphics capabilities.

signature.name: Packed-Ice True Colour Sprites [Spooky Sprites] (Atari Falcon)
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'ICE! {4-11} TCSF'

details.dc:description:
True Colour Sprites files are part of raster image graphics associated with Spooky Sprites, a graphics editor for Atari Falcon. This particular record identifies True Colour Sprites files that were compressed using Packed-Ice, a file compression tool used on Atari computers. Packed-Ice was developed by pseudonym "Axe of Delight", later changed to "Axe of Superior". There are several different versions of this compression tool. The files compressed using Packed-Ice program, start with ASCII "Ice!", or "ICE!", followed by a gap between 4-11 characters and then the magic bytes of the original file format.

details.dc:description: The Extensible File Allocation Table is a file system introduced by Microsoft in 2006, mainly for use in flash memory, such as USB flash drive and SD memory cards. It was a proprietary format until 2019, when Microsoft published its specification (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/exfat-specification). It may be possible and desirable to distinguish between different types of exFAT image. Please contact the PRONOM team if you can assist with this.

signature.name: Viacom New Media Graphics
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'VNM….€'

details.dc:description:
Viacom New Media Graphics is a graphics format developed by Viacom New Media, used to store images for early computer games. It is presumably graphics formats used in Beavis and Butthead in Virtual Stupidity video game.
Viacom New Media was a publisher of video games and other electronic entertainment software. It was formed in 1994 as a subdivision of Viacom Interactive Media.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: WRAptor Compressed File
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'ÿBLÿ'

details.dc:description:
WRAptor Compressed File is a format which was written by Bill Lucier, copyrighted in 1995, distributed by Loadstar and updated by Doreen Horne. This format is an uncommon compression format, capable of handling PRG, SEQ, USR and GEOS files (Sequential and VLIR), but not REL files. It utilizes a variant of the LZ (Lempel-Ziv) compression algorithm, starting at 9 bits per code. The 4-byte signature of this format is "FF 42 4C FF", with bytes 42 and 4C representing the authors initials in ASCII - "BL".
There are three versions of this format, all beginning with same magic bytes. The versions differentiate in their file extension with the v1 and v2 using .wra and the final v3 using .wr3. This entry records all versions of this file format. The complete manual of how to handle the software and this format is included with the reference links.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: XBIN (eXtended BIN)
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'XBIN.'

details.dc:description:
XBIN (eXtended BIN) is a character graphics format, widely used for ANSI art. It was designed to be a successor to BIN format [fmt/208] and uses a specialized run-lenght encoding (RLE) compression algorithm. Althought XBIN is considered to be a graphics format, it is not required to have an image. The format can be used for storing pre-made fonts and pre-made palettes which can be loaded from a viewer/editor. It is closely tied to the capabilities of the text modes of VGA graphics cards. The font can be customized, though limited to 16 colors only.
XBIN allows for binary images up to 65536 columns wide, and 65536 lines high, with an alternate set of palette colors either in blink or non-blink mode. It also allows for different textmode fonts from 1 to 32 scanlines high, consisting of either 256 or 512 different characters, and its file size is smaller by using more efficient compression system to its predecessor BIN format [fmt/208].

signature.note: Magic bytes, offset zero: Ð(carriage return)þí

details.dc:description: DeviceTree Blobs are a binary representation of a DeviceTree, which represents computer hardware layout, addresses, and interconnections. They enable details to be passed to the operating system as it boots up, instead of hard coding details of a device into that operating system. This signature describes version 17 of DeviceTree, however it may apply to other versions of the dtb file. Please get in touch if you have information which can help refine this signature.
details.dc:creator: DeviceTree / DeviceTree

record_metadata.dc:creator: Oliver Mattos / Oliver Mattos

signature.name: SGML/XML Entity File
signature.note: BOF offset zero, magic bytes: <!— EOF offset zero, magic bytes: -->.

details.dc:description: SGML/XML entity files are plain text files, often found alongside, and referenced by, xml and sgml files. Ent files list the parameters and entity declarations for a specific set of tags defined in a Document Type Definition.
details.dc:creator: W3C / W3C

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

details.dc:description: Files written in Pascal, or Object Pascal, programming language. The files are plain text (and as such can be edited using a plain text editor), and can then be compiled into executable programmes using a Pascal compiler, for example Turbo Pascal.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Art Of Noise - 4 Channel Module
signature.note: BOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes: AON4

details.dc:description: Aon files produced by ArtOfNoise music tracker software, freeware which was available on the Commodore Amiga. It was intended to be a soundtracker suited to synthetic songs, with a wider range of instruments and effects than comparable software. Originally made in 4 channel mode, a later 8 channel version was produced.

Originally made in 4 channel mode, a later 8 channel version was produced.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

details.dc:description: Files generated by ESRI ArcGIS mapping software (https://www.esri.com/en-us/arcgis/about-arcgis/overview). The .clr colour file is an optional file, which sits alongside .bil, .bip and .bsq files, and describes the image colour map for colour images: if there is no clr file, the image displays are grayscale. The clr file records colours for pixel values in the image using the RGB colour model (i.e. it lists the amount of red, green and blue contained in that pixel.

details.dc:description: Adobe InDesign is a desktop publishing application developed and produced by Adobe Inc., first released in 1999. It is the successor to PageMaker, software previously created by Aldus Corporation in 1985, which was subsequently acquired by Adobe. It can be used to produce a number of works such as posters, flyers, brochures, magazines, newspapers, presentations and books. InDesign supports XML, stylesheets and other coding markup, providing functionality for exporting tagged text content for use in other digital and online formats.
