signature.name: Inspiration Software File
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'application/x-inspiration....Created by software from Inspiration Software, Inc.{80-258}.JFIF'

pattern.regex: (?s)\Aapplication/x-inspiration Created by software from Inspiration Software, Inc\..{80,258}\x10JFIF

details.dc:description: The Inspiration Software File (ISF) is a format created by Inspiration software and files can be opened using the software. The Inspiration software was founded in 1982 by Donald Helfgott and Mona Westhaver, originally as a tool focused on business analytics, helping to build products to meet business needs. In 1996 the focus of the tool shifted to educational purposes, supporting educators and students across early and higher education. There are several known version of this software up to version 10 as the latest version in February 2021. The ISF files created on version 9 Inspiration software are identical to version 10, but version 7 and 8 ISF files lack the functionality to save data containing mind maps (as according to the manufacturer instructions, please see the web-links in Note section).

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Archives of Australia / National Archives of Australia

details.dc:description: Crystal Reports File is the proprietary format and main output file created by Crystal Reports, a business intelligence software. The software was created in 1991 and since then Crystal Reports has gone through multiple versions, though the file format structure has not changed dramatically.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints
record_metadata.dc:description: This format can be identified via a container signature in DROID version 6 or later. The PRONOM database cannot currently represent container signatures.

signature.name: AGS 4 Data Format
signature.note: Variable, magic bytes: “{0-1}PROJ_ID","{0-1}PROJ_NAME",”*“{0-1}ABBR_HDNG",”{0-1}ABBR_CODE","

details.dc:description: The AGS Data Format was created in 1991 by the Association of Geotechnical and Geoenvironmental Specialists, as a way of transferring data between different organisations in the geotechnical/geoenvironmental industry. It provides a way of exchanging said data reliably, independent of software/ hardware and operating system, and to a consistent standard.
details.dc:creator: AGS / Association of Geotechnical and Geoenvironmental Specialists
details.dcterms:publisher: Association of Geotechnical and Geoenvironmental Specialists

record_metadata.dc:creator: AGS / Association of Geotechnical and Geoenvironmental Specialists

details.dc:description: Bayesian Interchange files store the structure and probability tables for a Bayesian network, allowing for interchange of said networks between people, and facilitating comparison and discussion of research and other results.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

format.name: Garmin Flexible and Interoperable Data Transfer file

signature.name: Garmin Flexible and Interoperable Data Transfer file
signature.note: BOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes: FIT

details.dc:description: A file format developed by Garmin, for the storing and sharing of data from sports and health devices. Data is collected during a sporting activity, stored on the Garmin device, and can then be uploaded to the Garmin Connect web service, and other web applications. The format ensures that any .fit compliant device can interpret data from another .fit compliant device. The format allows users to track and compare data about their physical activities over time.
details.dc:creator: Garmin / Garmin

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: Typescript is a superset of Javascript, which adds additional syntax/ types. It has compilers that convert it to Javascript, enabling it to run wherever Javascript runs. Created by Microsoft, it was released as Open Source.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: Diplomatic Archives / French Ministry for Europe and Foreign Affairs

signature.name: STAD Pac File
signature.note: BOF:'pM' followed by either '35' or '36'

details.dc:description: STAD PAC is a raster graphics format developed by Peter Melzer and associated with the STAD (ST Aided Design) graphics application for Atari ST computers. File headers begin with either of two four character sequences (pM85 and pM86) dependent on whether the image data in the file is horizontally or vertically packed.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Palm Database ImageViewer Format
signature.note: BOF: Offset of 60 followed by 'vIMGView'

details.dc:description: Palm Database ImageViewer format is a type of Palm OS Database file. It contains a bitmap image and is associated with the Image Viewer III application. It is also known as FireViewer format and possibly also as TinyViewer format. It supports at least greyscale images with 2, 4 or 16 gray shades. Images may be uncompressed or use RLE compression.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

details.dc:description: Created by a free software cdrLabel, whose purpose was to make labels for CD jewel cases. It was able to make tables of contents using the CD contents. The last version of cdrLabel was 7.1, released in 2004. The output was the clb file, which contained the table of contents.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: Microsoft Help Contents File
signature.note: BOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes: :Base{1-259}.(hlp/HLP)

details.dc:description: Microsoft Help Contents Files store topics for a corresponding help document, which has file extension .hlp. They are found within applications which use Microsoft Help.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Canadian Centre for Architecture / The Canadian Centre for Architecture

signature.name: XIMG (Extended GEM Bit Image)
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'XIMG..'

details.dc:description:
The XIMG (Extended GEM Bit Image) image format is more developed version of GEM raster Image [x-fmt/159] which allows for standardised verison of storing colour palettes. It originated due to the specification of GEM format being ambiguous as to the format of color images.
The GEM raster format (also known as GEM VDI Bit Image; GEM Bit Image; GEM Image; GEM Bitmap; or IMG) is an image format native to the Graphical Environment Manager (GEM) operating system and developed at Digital Research. The format was used by GEM Paint and Ventura Publisher, and by a variety of Atari ST software.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: XL-Paint MaX
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'XLPM'

details.dc:description:
XL-Paint MaX is a graphic format used for storing images created by XL-Paint program, a program used for the Atari 8-bit family of computers, introduced in 1979.
The Atari 8-bit family is a series of 8-bit home computers introduced by Atari, Inc. All machines are based on the MOS Technology 6502 CPU running at 1.79 MHz, and were the first home computers designed with custom coprocessor chips.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: XL-Paint
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'XLPB'

details.dc:description:
XL-Paint is a graphic format used for storing images created by XL-Paint program, a program used for the Atari 8-bit family of computers, introduced in 1979. It uses .raw file extension, files begin with ASCII "XLPB" and are either 792 or 15372 bytes long.
The Atari 8-bit family is a series of 8-bit home computers introduced by Atari, Inc. All machines are based on the MOS Technology 6502 CPU running at 1.79 MHz, and were the first home computers designed with custom coprocessor chips.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Arts & Letters Clip Art Library
signature.note:
BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'CUSTOM, then 0x00'
EOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes; 'ÿÿ'

details.dc:description: Arts & Letters Clip Art Library format is a multi-image vector graphics format associated with the Arts & Letters application. Arts & Letters is a computer software for editing vector graphics. It was created by Computer Support Corporation and uses technology born on mainframes that migrated to the DOS platform in the 1980's.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Yamaha Audio Generic
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'LM8953.'

details.dc:description: Yamaha Wave Audio signature describes formats relevant to Yamaha Wave files, these formats are proprietary and created by Yamaha. There are several versions of these file formats with a numerous examples of extensions. This entry describes generic Yamaha wave format, and PRONOM holds a separate entry on Yamaha TX Wave Audio. Please contact the PRONOM team if you have more information regarding Yamaha Wave formats.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Yamaha TX Wave Audio
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'LM8953, then null bytes followed by wildcard bytes beween {16-21} then either bytes 0x49 or 0xC9, followed by 0x01'

details.dc:description: The Yamaha TX Wave Audio format is 12-bit audio wave file created by the Yamaha TX16W sampler. The Yamaha TX16W is a rack-mount sampler sound module with up to 50 kHz mono and 33 kHz stereo sampling. The format is proprietary created by Yamaha, similar to a .WAV file and supports 16, 33, and 50 kHz samples. The file consists of a 32 byte header followed by the actual waveform. This file fomat has multiple extensions, some of which have yet not been identified. The Yamaha SY Series Wave files also can use the same file extension and a simililar BOF sequence of 0x4C4D38393533. Please use links provided to view the full format specification.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

format.name: YAODL (Yet Another Object Description Language) File

signature.name: YAODL (Yet Another Object Description Language) File
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: '#YAODL, then 0x0D0A'

details.dc:description: SGI YAODL (Yet Another Object Description Language) is a description language used for storing 3D object data to disk files. YAODL is an obsolete format created specifically for the Silicon Graphics Powerflip demo program, but it is not widely supported by SGI. The format is an example of a basic vector-object description language and is stored in plain text (ASCII) format.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: RED Thumbnail File
signature.note: BOF:'REDTHUMBNAIL' followed by a gap of 3 hex pairs followed by 'rdi' followed by 0x01 (Start of Header) followed by a gap of 6 hex pairs followed by 0x18 (Cancel) followed by a gap of 3 hex pairs followed by 0x0C (Form Feed) followed by 'X' followed by 0x11 (Device Control 1) followed by 0x02 (Start of Text) followed by 0x03 (End of Text) followd by 'è' followed by a gap of 2 hex pairs followed by 'a'

details.dc:description: RED Digital Cinema is an American company manufacturing professional digital cinematography cameras and accessories, established in 2005. RED Thumbnail files are created by some models of RED digital cameras while shooting in an R3D + Apple ProRes, R3D + DNxHD/HR and in Avid DNxHD/HR only modes. These files bear the same root filename as the R3D file clip they are associated with and contain a randomly selected frame image to represent the clip in software.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

format.name: Easy CD Creator Layout | Roxio Easy CD Creator Layout

signature.name: Roxio Easy CD Creator Layout v5 & v6
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 0x10000000, then a gap of 1 byte followed by 0x0000000100000011000000

details.dc:description: This entry combines Easy CD Creator Layout version 5 with extension CL5 and Roxio Easy CD Creator Layout version 6 with extension RCL, which are both part of Roxio disc project formats. CL5 and RCL files are formed using Easy CD Creator, a software originally published by Adaptec in 1996 after Adaptec merged its Easy-CD Pro with Corel CD Creator, RCL files were part of Adaptec's re-brading to Roxio. CL5 version of Easy CD Creator Layout formats was published in 2001 after Adaptec spun-off their digital media division as Roxio, but prior to rebranding Easy CD Creator as Roxio Easy CD Creator - creating RCL files. Easy CD Creator software allowed the user to create data or audio CD layout by adding files or music in order to burn a disc. The layout only referenced the file location and not the files themselves. It allowed for files to be saved for later use with references to files that will be included on the disc as well as other settings. This format is a proprietary binary file, altered from earlier version CL2, CL3 and CL4 which are all Microsoft Compound File format, OLE2 container. The previous versions of this type of format have extensions CL2, CL3 and CL4. These earlier versions are seem to have very similar structure and cannot yet be distinguished in PRONOM. Please contact the PRONOM team in case you hold any more information regarding the earlier versions of this format.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: Roxio Easy Media Creator Layout v7
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 0x FFFE2300, followed by a wildcard bytes between 0-900, then '[RoxioINF20] [ProjectSettings] RCLVer=70'

details.dc:description: Roxio Easy Media Creator Layout version 7 with extension RCL is a part of Roxio disc project formats. RCL files are formed using Roxio Easy Media Creator software (previously named as Easy CD Creator and Roxio Easy CD Creator), originally published by Adaptec in 1996, this version follows the rebranding of the software to Roxio and was published around 2003. The format is different in hex structure to its predecessor version 6 (fmt/1665), with its hex sequence referencing the format version. Roxio Easy Media Creator software allowed the user to create data or audio CD layout by adding files or music in order to burn a disc. The layout only referenced the file location and not the files themselves. It allowed for files to be saved for later use with references to files that will be included on the disc as well as other settings.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

format.name: Roxio Easy Media Creator - Classic Creator File

signature.name: Roxio Easy Media Creator - Classic Creator File v8-10
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 0x FFFE2300, followed by a wildcard bytes between 0-900, then '[RoxioINF80] [ProjectSettings] RCLVer=80'

details.dc:description: Roxio Easy Media Creator Layout version 8 with extension RCL is a part of Roxio disc project formats. RCL files version 8 are formed using Creator Classic feature on Roxio Easy Media Creator software (previously named as Easy CD Creator and Roxio Easy CD Creator), originally published by Adaptec in 1996, this version follows the rebranding of the software to Roxio and was published around 2006. This format is a proprietary binary file and is similar to its predecessor version 7 with same extension RCL. It follows the header value 0xFFFE2300 followed later by the plain text "[RoxioINF80] [ProjectSettings] RCLVer=80" however, in contrast to its predecessor RLC version 7, which referres to 'layout' files on Roxio Easy Media Creator, RLC version 8 files are formed using the Creator Classic feature on Easy Media Creator. All following versions up to version 10 and Roxio Creator 2009-2010 of layout format on Roxio Easy Media Creator software, saved their 'layout' files in subsequent version with extension ROXIO, and their files created on Creator Classic feature as this format - RLC version 8. Roxio Easy Media Creator software allowed the user to create data or audio CD layout by adding files or music in order to burn a disc. The layout only referenced the file location and not the files themselves. It allowed for files to be saved for later use with references to files that will be included on the disc as well as other settings.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: Roxio Easy Media Creator Layout v8-10
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 0x 00BB00BB01

details.dc:description: Roxio Easy Media Creator Layout version 8 with extension ROXIO is a part of Roxio disc project formats. ROXIO files are formed Roxio Easy Media Creator software (previously named as Easy CD Creator and Roxio Easy CD Creator), originally published by Adaptec in 1996, this version follows the rebranding of the software to Roxio and was published around 2006. This format is a proprietary binary file just as its predecessor version 7 with extension RCL. The ROXIO file contains saved project, that stores information about audio, video or data disk compilation intended to be burned to disc. Roxio Easy Media Creator software allowed the user to create data or audio CD layout, it allowed for files to be saved for later use with references to files that will be included on the disc as well as other settings, but this format did not include the files themselves, only the information regarding these files. All versions up to version 10 and Roxio Creator 2009-2010 of layout format on Roxio Easy Media Creator software, saved their 'layout' files in ROXIO format. Corel then bought the Roxio products in 2012.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: Roxio Data Project File v11
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 160-260; Magic Bytes: '9CA0EEEE-5BC5-41e9-8242-BEE21643FFF0'

details.dc:description: Roxio Data Project File with extension ROX is a part of Roxio disc project formats. ROXIO files are formed Roxio Creator software (previously named as Roxio Easy Media Creator, Easy CD Creator and Roxio Easy CD Creator), originally published by Adaptec in 1996, this version replaces the ROXIO format (fmt/1668) was published around 2011. This format is a binary file just as its predecessors however, unlike other versions, the format is XML type of file with its structure distinguishing between Data and Audio files. Previously the ROXIO file contained all saved project, that stores information about audio, video or data disk compilation intended to be burned to disc. Roxio Creator software allows the user to create data or audio CD layout, it allows for files to be saved for later use with references to files that will be included on the disc as well as other settings, but this format did not include the files themselves, only the information regarding these files. All versions up to version 10 and Roxio Creator 2009-2010 of layout format on Roxio Easy Media Creator software, saved their 'layout' files in ROXIO format, but this format only saves data type files, see separate entry for audio (fmt/1670).

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: Roxio Audio Project File v11
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 169-260; Magic Bytes: '10253C4C-229D-4c87-8D1D-169EFDFED869'

details.dc:description: Roxio Audio Project File with extension ROX is a part of Roxio disc project formats. ROX files are formed Roxio Creator software (previously named as Roxio Easy Media Creator, Easy CD Creator and Roxio Easy CD Creator), originally published by Adaptec in 1996, this version replaces the ROXIO format (fmt/1668) was published around 2011. This format is a binary file just as its predecessors however, unlike other versions, the format is XML file with its structure distinguishing between Data and Audio files. Previously the ROXIO file contained all saved project, that stores information about audio, video or data disk compilation intended to be burned to disc. Roxio Creator software allows the user to create data or audio CD layout, it allows for files to be saved for later use with references to files that will be included on the disc as well as other settings, but this format did not include the files themselves, only the information regarding these files. All versions up to version 10 and Roxio Creator 2009-2010 of layout format on Roxio Easy Media Creator software, saved their 'layout' files in ROXIO format, but this format only saves audio type files, see separate entry for data files (fmt/1669).

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: Z Compressed Data
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 0x1F9D90

details.dc:description: Z Compressed Data are files that have been compressed by Unix's shell compression program, compress. The compress software was developed by Spences Thomas in 1984 and uses LZW algorithm. The format has lossless data, it can be compressed and decompressed using the Unix and Linux operating systems.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Linux/i386 Binary Executable File ZMAGIC
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: Starting with either 0x07, 0x0B, 0xCC followed by either 0x00 or 0x01, then by 0x6400

details.dc:description: ZMAGIC file format is a type of a.out (an abbreviated form of "assembler output") executible binary format used with Unix-like operating systems. The format was superseeded by ELF file format with System V Release 4 around 1898, due to some limitations of the format. The ZMAGIC was the default a.out file format before they switched to QMAGIC files. Both formats of executable have a 32 byte header at the start of the file, but with ZMAGIC the .text section starts at byte offset 1024, while with QMAGIC the .text section starts at the beginning of the file and includes the header.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Zbrush MatCap
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'ZBrushFile', then 0x2E

details.dc:description: ZBrush Material format is used with 3-D materials by the ZBrush software. It is used with the MatCap (Material Capture) tool that uses calibration markers to capture information from photographs and other images. Each of these markers samples a single point on the image and defines the colour, texture and lightining of the surface to build up a material map that simulates the lighting and material properties from the photograph. The HDRP replaces all of the materials and lighting in the scene with what is in the MatCap.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: ZyXEL Voice Format Audio
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'ZyXEL' followed by 0x02

details.dc:description: ZyXEL Voice Audio files were originally developed by Zyxel Communications for the Zyxel Z-Fax modem software application. These files are capable of digitizing speech to transfer data through software such as Z-Fax or VoiceConnect, using compression betweeen 19.2k CPS(ADPCM) and 9.6k CPS (CELP).

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: IntelliFont Font File
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 0x00440001000000{2}000002

details.dc:description: IntelliFont Font file is a format belonging to IntelliFont utility developed by Tom Hawkins at Compugraphic in Wilmington during the late 1980s. The font utility is native to AmigaOS, it was originally developed by Compugraphic Corporation, which was later acquired by Agfa, later becoming Monotype. This font format appears to be LHZ archive which holds data specific to create IntelliFont requirements.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Covox ADPCM Audio Files | Covox 8-bit audio
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 0xFF55FFAAFF55FFAA

details.dc:description: Covox ADPCM Audio Files (also known as Covox 8-bit audio) is a title for a family of Adaptive Differential Pulse Code Modulation (ADPCM) formats, used for compressing 8-bit unsigned pulse code modulation. They were invented by Covox for use with Covox sound output devices. ADPCM is a lossy compression format containing audio data that are optimized for storing digitally recorded or sampled voice data.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: Microsoft Office File List
signature.note: BOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes <xml xmlns:o="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office"> <o:MainFile Href=".. EOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes: </xml>

details.dc:description: These are xml files generated when a format requiring multiple files is saved by Microsoft Office Programmes (for example, an html page with images). The files are saved alongside the document in a folder called filename_files , and are named filelist.xml. The purpose of the files is to provide a list of all the files which were saved as part of the document, for example the html pages, and the images.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

details.dc:description: MATLAB (an abbreviation of MATrix LABoratory) software and language enables the user to undertake numerical computation and visualization, programme and analyze data, develop algorithms, and create models. Files with extension m are the source code that executes MATLAB commands. A single MATLAB simulation can contain multiple .m files, each one performing a different function.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Technische Informationsbibliothek (TIB) Hannover / Technische Informationsbibliothek (TIB) Hannover

signature.name: Garmin track log file
signature.note: BOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes: <@gArMiN@>

details.dc:description: Gmn files are used within Garmin Forerunner watches, which track GPS and heart rate data when work by the user during exercise. Gmn files store data relating to the exercise session, which can include heart rate, altitude, timestamp and position (latitude and longitude).

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: INTREPID Standard Information File
signature.note: BOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes: MetaData Begin...Name.= EOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes: End..MetaData End..

details.dc:description: INTREPID Standard Information Files are a format developed by Australian company Intrepid Geophysics, used by their INTREPID software for processing and visualising geophysical data. isi files are vector files which can capture a variety of data. Every INTREPID dataset has an isi file which contains, amongst other information, the parameter values for the dataset.
details.dc:creator: Intrepid Geophysics / Intrepid Geophysics

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: OBO Flat File Format
signature.note: BOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes: format-version: 1.2

details.dc:description: OBO Flat File Format version 1.2 files are text files generated by the software OBO-Edit, an open source application for editing and viewing ontologies, which is no longer being updated. The OBO flat file format is an ontology representation language, enabling the user to model concepts that are not supported in other description logic languages.
details.dc:creator: Gene Ontology / Gene Ontology

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: EndNote Library file format is generated and used via EndNote reference management software application. EndNote is a software intended for the management of bibliographies and references when producing academic text or reports. Endnote software was first launched in 1989 by Niles & Associates, then in 2000 was acquired by Institute for Scientific Information’s Research Soft Division, and since 2016 owned by Clarivate. The EndNote Library file format stores the references and citations in so called 'libraries' used with the software. Users of EndNote application can create their own EndNote Library files, as well as upload EndNote Library files onto their software. The latter versions of this software starting from version 8, include .data folder to accompany the EndNote Library format, the .data folder is automatically created by EndNote, intended to store attachments. Following this update, the data folder is recommended to be present in the EndNote Library file structure in order to use the EndNote Library format with the EndNote software. This entry describes versions X and all sequential to version X9, which changed from binary type of file format to ZIP container. In later versions starting from version X users have the ability to compress EndNote Library files using the EndNote application in purpose to share their files with other EndNote users. The record of the Compressed EndNote Library file format as well as, subsequent versions, which were named starting from version 20, are included in separate PRONOM entry. Please see the full version history using the Web Archive Wikipedia entry link included in the Notes section.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints
record_metadata.dc:description: This format can be identified via a container signature in DROID version 6 or later. The PRONOM database cannot currently represent container signatures.

details.dc:description: EndNote Library file format is generated and used via EndNote reference management software application. EndNote is a software indented for the management of bibliographies and references when producing academic text or reports. Endnote software was first launched in 1989 by Niles & Associates, then in 2000 was acquired by Institute for Scientific Information’s Research Soft Division, and since 2016 owned by Clarivate. The EndNote Library file format stores the references and citations in so called 'libraries' used with the software. Users of EndNote application can create their own EndNote Library files, as well as upload EndNote Library files onto their software. The latter versions of this software starting from version 8, include .data folder to accompany the EndNote Library format, the .data folder is automatically created by EndNote, intended to store attachments. Following this update, the data folder is recommended to be present in the EndNote Library file structure in order to use the EndNote Library format with the EndNote software. This entry describes compressed versions X and all sequential to version X9, which changed from binary type of file format to ZIP container. In these later versions an ability to compress EndNote Library files using the EndNote application was added, in purpose to easily share EndNote library files with other EndNote users. Subsequent versions altered their file format structure to SQL Lite database and are included in separate PRONOM entry. details.dc:description: Microsoft Word for MS-DOS Document is a proprietary binary format of Microsoft Word, word processing application, for MS-DOS first released in 1983. The first version was released on IBM PC DOS, developed by Microsoft, which Microsoft then re-branded as MS-DOS. The version was developed by Charles Simonyi and Richard Brodie firstly for Xenix in February 1983 (titled as "Multi-Tool Word") and in October 1983 for MS-DOS operating systems. The application featured graphics video mode, mouse and printer support (printer support was added in version 2) in WYSIWYG (What You See Is What You Get) interface and could run in text mode or graphics mode, with bold, italics, and underline features only available in the text mode. The version 6 of the format was released in 1993, with the release of Word for MS-MOS, which was the last version for MS-DOS and was releases at the same time as Word 6.0 for Word and version 6.0 for Macintosh. The MS-DOS version 6 file format was different from those for Windows and Macintosh and the Word 6.0 for DOS macro language was compatible with the Word 3.x-5.x macro language, whilst Word 6.0 for Windows and Word 6.0 for Macintosh inherited WordBasic from the Word 1.0/2.0 for Windows code base. Please see the full list of versions using the links provided in the Notes section.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

format.name: Microsoft Word for MS-DOS Glossary File

signature.name: Microsoft Word for MS-DOS Glossary File (Generic)
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 0x31BE010000AB0000000000000000

details.dc:description: Microsoft Word for MS-DOS Glossary is proprietary format of Microsoft Word application used on MS-DOS operating system. It includes data that helps convert glossary terms between versions of Word. Microsoft Word for MS-DOS application featured graphics video mode and mouse support in WYSIWYG (What You See Is What You Get) interface. The application could run in text mode or graphics mode with little visual difference between the two modes. The Microsoft Word, word processing application for MS-DOS, was first released in 1983. There were several versions of Microsoft Word for MS-DOS from version 1 in 1983 to last version released in 1993. Each of these versions included support for glossary (.gly) file format. The header for each version is similar to the .doc file format header but with one byte (3) difference. This is a generic entry for this format however, other versions respond to the same byte pattern in different versions as .doc formats for MS-DOS. Please see the full list of versions in PRONOM and using the links provided in the Notes section as well as, the manual for MS-DOS versions 1x which can be downloaded from WinWorld.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

format.name: Microsoft Word for MS-DOS Style Sheet File

signature.name: Microsoft Word for MS-DOS Style Sheet File (Generic)
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 0x31BE020000AB0000000000000000

details.dc:description: Microsoft Word for MS-DOS Style Sheet is proprietary format of Microsoft Word application used on MS-DOS operating system. The Microsoft Word, word processing application for MS-DOS, was first released in 1983. Microsoft Word for MS-DOS application featured graphics video mode and mouse support in WYSIWYG (What You See Is What You Get) interface. The application could run in text mode or graphics mode with little visual difference between the two modes. There were several versions of Microsoft Word for MS-DOS released, from version 1 in 1983 to last version released in 1993. Each of these versions included support for style sheets (.sty) file format. The header for each version is similar to the .doc file format header but with one byte (3) difference. This is a generic entry for this format however, other versions respond to the same byte pattern in different versions as .doc formats for MS-DOS. Please see the full list of versions in PRONOM and using the links provided in the Notes section as well as, the manual for MS-DOS versions 1x which can be downloaded from WinWorld.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

format.name: Microsoft Word for MS-DOS Printer Description File

signature.name: Microsoft Word for MS-DOS Printer Description File (Generic)
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 0x31BE030000AB0000000000000000

details.dc:description: Microsoft Word for MS-DOS Printer Description File is proprietary format of Microsoft Word application used on MS-DOS operating system. The Microsoft Word, word processing application for MS-DOS, was first released in 1983. Microsoft Word for MS-DOS application featured graphics video mode and mouse support in WYSIWYG (What You See Is What You Get) interface. The application could run in text mode or graphics mode with little visual difference between the two modes. There were several versions of Microsoft Word for MS-DOS from version 1 in 1983 to last version released in 1993. Each of these versions included support for printers by using the Printer Description File. These files were to be copied from Word Utilities disk to the Word Program disk which correspond to the printer being used. Additionally, Microsoft Word for MS-DOS included TTY Printer Description File, labelled as TTY.PRD, which supported teletype printing, and teletype printing with backspace files labelled as TTYBS.PRD. The header for each version is similar to the .doc file format header but with one byte (3) difference. This is a generic entry for this format however, other versions respond to the same byte pattern in different versions as .doc formats for MS-DOS. Please see the full list of versions in PRONOM and using the links provided in the Notes section as well as, the manual for MS-DOS versions 1x which can be downloaded from WinWorld.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

format.name: ESRI ArcGIS Raw Raster Reader/ Writer

signature.name: ESRI ArcGIS Raw Raster Reader/ Writer with header
signature.note: BOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes: ARC/INFO file created from ER Mapper{4-257}byteorder{3-4}nbits 8{3-4}xdim{1-15}ydim{1-15}ncols{2-6}nrows{4-6}nbands{3-4}ulxmap{9-15}ulymap

signature.name: ESRI ArcGIS Raw Raster Reader/ Writer
signature.note: BOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes: BYTEORDER{7}.LAYOUT{9}BIL.NROWS{13-15}.NCOLS{13-16}.NBANDS{10}.NBITS{12}.BANDROWBYTES{7-8}.TOTALROWBYTES{6-7}PIXELTYPE

details.dc:description: These are hdr files generated by ESRI ArcGIS software. They are associated with other ArcGIS formats, .BIL, .BIP and .BSQ. All of these formats are methods of organising mapping raster image data, and the .HDR file stores the attributes of the image, eg. column and line numbers, and byte order. Esri have produced several types of GIS software (for example ArcGIS Pro, ArcPad, ArcMap), and it is not clear which software or version these signatures apply to. If you have any information on ESRI hdr files, please get in touch.
details.dc:creator: Esri / Esri

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: Asymetrix Compel Presentation v1.0

details.dc:description: Asymetrix Compel Presentation files are proprietary formats belonging to Compel software application, developed by Asymetrix Learning Systems Corporation. Compel is a presentation software, a tool to create slide-based multimedia presentations. There were two versions published of this software first published in 1993 and second published in 1995, the software was discontinued in 1998. This format entry describes version 1.0 of this software. The software also could export .art files which seems to have very similar structure.

signature.name: OGC GeoPackage
signature.note: BOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes: SQLite format 3{53}GP*gpkg_spatial_ref_sys

details.dc:description: A Geopackage is designed for transferring geospatial information in a platform-independent, portable, open and standards based way. It is a standard describing a set of conventions for storing vector features, extensions and tile matrix sets of imagery and raster maps at various scales within a SQLite database. It was defined and published by the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) in 2014.
details.dc:creator: OpenDWG Alliance

signature.name: Persuasion Mac Document v1
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 0x0008 then a sequence of five wildcard bytes followed by 0x0003

details.dc:description: Persuasion Mac Document format is part of Adulus Persuasion format family. The format is created using the Aldus Persuasion (now discontinued) presentation program software developed by Peter Polash in 1988 for the Macintosh platform by Aldus Corporation. Following a merger of Adobe Systems and Adulus Corporation in 1994, the software was re-branded to Adobe Persuasion and a Microsoft Windows version was released. ere were two versions released for Macintosh only, then starting with version 2.x, a version for Windows was released with each new release up to version 4. Adobe discontinued production of the software in September 1997. This format entry describes the first version of the format which can often have no format extension attached to files.

signature.name: Persuasion Presentation Interchange File
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 0x524F4F54 then a gap of 4 wildcard bytes followed by 0x50726573656E746174696F6E20496E7465726368616E67652046696C6520466F726D6174

details.dc:description: Persuasion Presentation Interchange File is part of Aldus Persuasion format family. The format was created in 1995 following the merger of Adulus Corporation with Adobe Systems, re-branding the software to Adobe Persuasion and creating versions for Microsoft Windows. Since the file formats for Macintosh and Windows differ, the intechange format was introduced to allow for transfer between these platforms. Aldus Persuasion is now discontinued presentation program software first developed by Peter Polash in 1988 for the Macintosh.

details.dc:description: Auto-Template Interchange File is part of Aldus Persuasion format family. The format stores template files for use on Aldus Persuasion. Adulus Persuasion is a presentation program software first developed by Peter Polash in 1988 for the Macintosh. Following a merger of Adobe Systems and Adulus Corporation in 1994, the software was re-branded to Adobe Persuasion and a Microsoft Windows version was released. There were two versions released for Macintosh only, then starting with version 2.x, a version for Windows was released with each new release up to version 4. Version 4 was released in 1996 and was bundled with other Adobe applications, including over 100 templates. Adobe discontinued production of the software in September 1997.

details.dc:description: Time Stamp Tokens contain a hash of data which is being time stamped, electronically signed by a Timestamping Authority. For example, tst files might be generated to prove a digital signature was created before a given time. The hash refers to data objects carried in ASiC containers.

details.dc:description: PageMaker is a discontinued desktop publishing program created by Aldus Corporation in 1985. Originally created for Macintosh computers the PC version was released in 1987. It was purchased alongside other Aldus software such as FreeHand in 1994. File extensions begin with either p or t, signifying the PageMaker file or PageMaker template, followed by the version number 65 or with the extension pmd or pmt.
details.dc:creator: Adobe Systems Incorporated

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

details.dc:description: PageMaker is a discontinued desktop publishing program created by Aldus Corporation in 1985. Originally created for Macintosh computers the PC version was released in 1987. It was purchased alongside other Aldus software such as FreeHand in 1994. File extensions begin with either pm or pt, for the PageMaker file or for PageMaker template, followed by the version number.

signature.name: Portable Compiled Format
signature.note: BOF: 0x01 (Start of Header) followed by 'fcp'

details.dc:description: Portable Compiled Format (PCF) is a bitmap font format used by X Windows System in its core font system. PCF fonts are usually installed by default on most Uni-based operating systems and are used in terminals such as xterm. It gradually became more widely used than the Glyph Bitmap Distribution (BDF) format but has more recently been superseded by OpenType and TrueType fonts.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Pablo Paint Raster Image
signature.note: BOF:'PABLO PACKED PICTURE: Groupe CDND ' followed by 0x0D (Carriage Return) followed by 0x0A (Line Feed)

details.dc:description: Pablo Paint is a raster image format originating from the Atari line of computers. It has two known extensions. The first is .ppp and is reserved for lower resolution images. The second is .pa3 and is associated with higher resolution images. Both are identified by the same internal signature.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

signature.name: BIM Metadata File
signature.note: BOF:0x00 (Null) followed by 0x1F (Unit Seperator) followed by 0x01 (Start of Header) followed by '4urn:schemas-professionalDisc:realTimeMeta:cameraMeta' followed by 0x1C (File Seperator) followed by './RealTimeMetaCameraMeta.xsd' followed by 0x00 (Null)

details.dc:description: BIM is a RealTime metadata file that is stored alongside the image files on cameras such as the Sony FS7. It can contain information such as focus distance, shutter speed, aperture in relation to time.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: Files from Wordcraft word processing software from the 1980s, which was made for IBM XT and Commodore 64. Documents created with this software contained at least 2 files, an 'index' file with extension .doc and chapter file(s) with extension .001.
details.dc:creator: Wordcraft International Limited

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: LegalDocML Document
signature.note: BOF: XML declaration: '<?xml version=("OR')1.0("OR')' followed by a gap between 0-1024 bytes followed by namespace declaration: '<akomaNtoso' then 0-1024 bytes later, 'xmlns="http://docs.oasis-open.org/legaldocml/ns/akn/3.0'

details.dc:description: LegalDocML is an open standard maintained by the LegalDocML Technical Committee under the OASIS Standards body. It is an XML-based standard for describing the structure of legal documents.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Preservica / Preservica

signature.name: Capture One Settings File

details.dc:description: File created by created by Capture One software which performs photo editing, raw image file processing of many different raw file types, and image cataloguing. Capture One does not make changes to the original RAW file, instead storing them as adjustments within these component files: Cos files contain the adjustments made to images.
details.dc:creator: Capture One

signature.name: Pro Tools Session File
signature.note: BOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes:.0010111100101011{3}Z…

details.dc:description: File created every time a user sets up a session in Pro Tools, music creation software made by Avid, which allows the user to create, record and mix music. Every time a session is started, a ptx file is created, containing all plug ins, audio and midi tracks and mixer settings. They do not contain actual audio, but have audio files linked to them.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of New Zealand / National Library of New Zealand

signature.name: dBASE Windows Form File
signature.note: BOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes: ** END HEADER -- do not remove this line* * Generated on {2}/{2}/{2-4} *

pattern.regex: (?s)\A\*\* END HEADER -- do not remove this line\*\r\n\* Generated on .{2}/.{2}/.{2,4}\r\n\*

details.dc:description: dBASE is a database management systems for personal computers. The dBASE system includes the core database engine, a query system, a forms engine, and a programming language that ties all of these components together. The wfm file stores the dBASE form, used for entering and modifying data in the database.
details.dc:creator: dBASE Inc.

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: Esri Shapefile Geospatial Metadata File
signature.note: BOF, offset 0-250, magic bytes: <metadata xml:lang="en"><Esri> EOF offset 0-5: </metadata>

details.dc:description: Esri Shapefile (actually a collection of files), was introduced with ArcView GIS software in the early 1990s, but is now used within a wide variety of software. It enables geographical datasets to be used between Esri and other GIS software. Esri Shapefiles consist of a collection of files within a directory. They always have files with extension shp, shx and dbf. The actual shapefile is the .shp file, but the other files are required supporting files. The shp.xml file is not mandatory, and stores geospatial metadata in xml format.
details.dc:creator: Esri / Esri

record_metadata.dc:creator: Yan Han / University of Arizona Library

details.dc:description: .dat files are used by many different applications as a general data store. Some may have a precise structure, but this entry is intended as a catch-all for extension-only identification for those .dat formats that do not yet have a PRONOM identification signature. For ESRI ArcInfo DAT File (Internal), see fmt/1600.

signature.name: PowerGraphics Image File

details.dc:description:
Prism Paint Bitmap is a raster graphics format associated with the Prism Paint program for Atari computers. It usually uses PackBits compression.
It is likely to be the same as the TruePaint TPI format.

signature.name: PaintShop Plus Compressed Format

signature.name: Portfolio Graphics Compressed File
signature.note: BOF:'PG' followed by 0x01 (Start of Header)

details.dc:description: PGC is a bi-level image file format used on the Atari Portfolio palmtop computer which utilises RLE compression. The image dimensions are always 240 x 64 pixels.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives and Records Administration / The National Archives and Records Administration

details.dc:description: C/C++ Header File can come with extension .hpp, .hxx or .h and are text header files written in the C or C++ programming language. File extension .h are preffered to be used in C programming language but are also compatable with C++. The .hpp extension is preffered to be used in C++ header file (the "pp" in extension presumably stands for "plus, plus"). These files are mainly categorized as developer files using the correct file extension, they can be inserted to a .cpp source code file, provided the “#include directive” is used. Due to type of this file format a magic bytes sequence could not be established and this format is only recognised by its exension, please contact the PRONOM team if you can provide any more information.

record_metadata.dc:creator: UMC Utrecht / University Medical Center Utrecht

signature.name: Creative Voice File
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; 'Creative Voice File'

details.dc:description: Creative Voice File is an audio format developed in the 1990s developed by Creative Labs for the storage of uncompressed PCM audio data for use on Sound Blaster boards.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Flow Cytometry Standard File
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 'FCS' followed by a version number then followed by space characters, followed by at least three pairs of ASCII-encoded integers indicating the byte offsets for the start and end (=last byte of) of the primary TEXT segment, the DATA segment, and the ANALYSIS segment

details.dc:description: Flow Cytometry Standard (FCS) is a format originating from data file standard for reading and writing of data from flow cytometry experiments written by International Society for Advancement of Cytometry (ISAC). FCS format describes a file that is a combination of textual data followed by binary data. The first version of the format was adopted as FCS 1.0 in 1984, and then was modified in 1990 as FCS 2.0 and again in 1997 as FCS 3.0, with the latest version of the standard introduced in 2010 as version 3.1. Please see the links attached with this entry to find file specification.
details.dc:creator: ISAC / International Society for Advancement of Cytometry
details.dcterms:publisher: International Society for Advancement of Cytometry

record_metadata.dc:creator: UMC Utrecht / University Medical Center Utrecht

signature.name: UDF Disc Image
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 32768; Max Offset: 36864; Magic Bytes: 0x00424541303101, then an exact of 2041 wildcard bytes, followed by 0x004E535230, then either 0x32 or 33 followed by 0x01

details.dc:description: UDF Disc Image is a format that stores contents and structure of an optical disc which can be transferred on the other media. It uses Universal Disk Format (UDF) file system developed for optical media by the Optical Storage Technology Association (OSTA). It is a portable format that is recognized by several operating systems, and considered to be a successor of ISO 9660 capable to manage read/write media in better capacity. UDF is used for computer data storage for a broad range of media, including DVDs and Blu-Ray disks. A disk image is a uncompressed copy of the contents of a disk or a folder, it can facilitate certain types of backup and recovery strategies. Please see ID: fdd000348 from Library of Congress and other links attached to this entry for further information.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: UDF-ISO 9660 Bridge Disc
signature.note:
BOF; Offset: 32768; Max Offset: 70468; Magic Bytes: 0x4344303031, then wildcard bytes between 1 to 16384, followed by 0xFF4344303031
&
BOF; Offset: 32768; Max Offset: 70468; Magic Bytes: 0x00424541303101, then an exact of 2041 wildcard bytes, followed by 0x004E535230, then either 0x32 or 33 followed by 0x01

details.dc:description: UDF-ISO 9660 Bridge Disc is a format that stores contents and structure of an optical disc which can be transferred on the other media. It uses Universal Disk Format (UDF) file system developed for optical media by the Optical Storage Technology Association (OSTA), as well as ISO 9660 International Organization for Standardization (ISO). This format acts as a support for discs where ISO 9660 and UDF formats all reside on the same optical disc. It can be used in video applications, such as DVD-Video, DVD+VR, and DVD-VR. A disk image is a uncompressed copy of the contents of a disk or a folder, it can facilitate certain types of backup and recovery strategies. Please see ID: fdd000348 from Library of Congress and other links attached to this entry for further information.

signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: wildcard bytes between 0 to 16 bytes, followed by 0x45520200, an exact 508 wildcard bytes followed by 0x504D

signature.name: Apple Partition Map Disk Image, sig n.2
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: wildcard bytes between 0 to 16 bytes, followed by 0x45520800, an exact 2044 wildcard bytes followed by 0x504D

signature.name: Apple Partition Map Disk Image, sig n.3
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: wildcard bytes between 0 to 16 bytes, followed by a set of null bytes, then an exact 508 wildcard bytes followed by 0x504D

details.dc:description: Apple Partition Map Disk Image is specific to describing the contents and structure of Apple Partition Map (APM) partition scheme, it can be thought of as a container format for multiple filesystem image files. It was developed by Apple in around 1988 with the introduction of Apple Partition Map scheme on Macintosh II, a scheme that defines how the data is organized on a singular disk. A disk image is a uncompressed copy of the contents of a disk or a folder, it can facilitate certain types of backup and recovery strategies. Please see ID: fdd000348 from Library of Congress and other links attached to this entry for further information.

signature.name: Apple Partition Map ISO 9660 Hybrid, sig n.1
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 32768; Max Offset: 70468; Magic Bytes: wildcard bytes between 0 to 16 bytes, followed by 0x45520200, an exact 508 wildcard bytes followed by 0x504D4344303031, then wildcard bytes between 1 to 16384, followed by 0xFF4344303031

signature.name: Apple Partition Map ISO 9660 Hybrid, sig n.2
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 32768; Max Offset: 70468; Magic Bytes: wildcard bytes between 0 to 16 bytes, followed by 0x45520800, an exact 2044 wildcard bytes followed by 0x504D4344303031, then wildcard bytes between 1 to 16384, followed by 0xFF4344303031

details.dc:description: Apple Partition Map ISO 9660 Hybrid is a hybrid to describing the contents and structure of Apple Partition Map (APM) partition scheme and ISO9660 file system for optical disc media. The hybrid system allows for ISO9660 as a primary volume descriptor and an Apple Partition Map, allowing the disc to work on different types of computers. Apple Partition Map was developed by Apple in around 1988 with the introduction of Macintosh II. ISO 9660 was written by International Organization for Standardization (ISO) and considered an international technical standard available for many operating systems. A disk image is a uncompressed copy of the contents of a disk or a folder, it can facilitate certain types of backup and recovery strategies. Please see ID: fdd000348 from Library of Congress and other links attached to this entry for further information.

format.name: Hierarchical File System Plus
format.alias: HFS+, Mac OS Extended, HFS Extended

signature.name: Hierarchical File System Plus, sig n.1
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 1024; Magic Bytes: 0x482B0004 & EOF; Offset: 1024; Magic Bytes: 0x482B0004

signature.name: Hierarchical File System Plus, sig n.2
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 1024; Magic Bytes: 0x48580005 & EOF; Offset: 1024; Magic Bytes: 0x48580005

details.dc:description: Hierarchical File System Plus (also known as HFS+, Mac OS Extended or HFS Extended) is a file system developed by Apple Inc. as a successor to the Hierarchical File System (HFS) [fmt/1105]. The system was introduced in January 1998 with the release of Mac OS 8.1 and continued to be the primary file system on Apple operating systems starting with Mac OS X, as well as one of the primary file systems used by the iPod portable media player. It features improvements to HFS, such as a 32-bit file length field rather than 16-bit to allow for much longer files names and adds support for Unicode characters in file names up to 255 characters long, containing any characters in the Unicode repertoire (though there may be OS or API-specific restrictions on permittable characters). Journaling was added in 2003 and case-sensitive file names were introduced under the HFSX option. It was replaced with the Apple File System (APFS) released with macOS High Sierra in 2017.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: Nero Burning ROM Image File
signature.note: EOF; Offset: 0-12; Magic Bytes: 0x4E4552(35|4F)

details.dc:description: Nero Burning ROM Image File (NRG) is a proprietary disc image format associated with Nero Burning ROM software. It acts as the utility of Nero Burning ROM and is used to create backups or copies of data for discs. This is a generic entry of NRG file format but there are two versions of this format. Its first version was launched in 1997 and was specified to store values as 32-bit integers. Its second version was introduced with version 5.5 of Nero Burning ROM software in 2001 and supports 64-bit integers.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: Psion Series 3 Bitmap
signature.note: BOF:'PICÜ00'

details.dc:description: Psion Series 3 Bitmap (also known as Psion PIC or EPOC PIC) is a raster image file format associated with Psion's EPOC operating system, and used mainly on Psion PDA devices. A Psion PIC file contains one or more bi-level bitmaps. Sometimes, two bitmaps need to be combined to make a 4-tone grayscale image.

signature.name: Microsoft PowerPoint Presentation v2
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 0xEDDEAD0B02000000

details.dc:description: Microsoft PowerPoint Presentation is a proprietary binary file format developed by Microsoft Corporation used to store presentation files created in the Microsoft PowerPoint presentation system. This record describes version 2 of .ppt file format released in May 1990 for Windows, and included in the first version of Microsoft Office for Windows. Versions up to version 4 [x-fmt/88] of Microsoft PowerPoint use .ppt as extension however, they are not compatible with each other. Microsoft made backwards compatibility an optional add-on after Office 2003 and appears to have removed it altogether in Office 2010. Please follow the links attached to this entry for more information.
details.dc:creator: Microsoft Corporation

signature.name: Microsoft PowerPoint Presentation v3
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 0xEDDEAD0B03000000

details.dc:description: Microsoft PowerPoint Presentation is a proprietary binary file format developed by Microsoft Corporation used to store presentation files created in the Microsoft PowerPoint presentation system. This record describes version 3 of .ppt file format released in May 1992 for Windows, and included in the 3.0 version of Microsoft Office for Windows released in August 1992. Versions up to version 4 [x-fmt/88] of Microsoft PowerPoint use .ppt as extension however, they are not compatible with each other. Microsoft made backwards compatibility an optional add-on after Office 2003 and appears to have removed it altogether in Office 2010. Please follow the links attached to this entry for more information.

signature.name: Canon MIF File
signature.note: BOF:'MI' followed by 0x01 (Start of Header) followed by 0x01 (Start of Header) followed by 0x02 (Start of Text)

details.dc:description: A Canon MIF file is present in the Canon XF folder structure that is used by media cards associated with cameras such as XF205 and C300. It contains information about each clip recorded on the media card, is found within the CANON XF/CLIPS 001 directory and is a strict requirement in order to mount a particular card in Canon media apps to make the content readable. Although little official documentation exists, MIF likely stands for Media Information File.
details.dc:creator: Canon / Canon

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Canon CIF File
signature.note: BOF:'CI' followed by 0x01 (Start of Header) followed by 0x00 (Null) followed by 0x11 (Device Control 1) followed by 0x14 (Device Control 4) followed by 0x11 (Device Control 1) followed by 0x10 (Data Link Escape)

details.dc:description: A Canon CIF file is present in the Canon XF folder structure that is used by media cards associated with cameras such as XF205 and C300. It contains information identifying the clip and the camera used, including type, serial number and version. Additionally, it stores some information which can be seen and edited in the Canon XF Utility, such as the Clip Status (OK/Check/None). It is found within each CANON XF/CLIPS 001/AAxxxx directory, where xxxx is an automatically generated number beginning with 0001. A full copy of the file exists within the INDEX.MIF file (fmt/1749) found within the CANONXF/CLIPS001 directory. Although little official documentation exists, CIF likely stands for Clip Information File.
details.dc:creator: Canon / Canon

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Canon SIF File
signature.note: BOF: 0x01 (Start of Header) followed by 0x00 (Null) followed by 0x02 (Start of Text) followed by 0x00 (Null)

details.dc:description: A Canon SIF file is present in the Canon XF folder structure that is used by media cards associated with cameras such as XF205 and C300. It is created whenever a video file is shot and exceeds the 2GB file size limit imposed by the FAT32 filesystem. In this case, an SIF file is created for each corresponding MXF file. It is found within the CANON XF/CLIPS 001/AAxxxx directory, where xxxx is an automatically generated number beginning with 0001. Although little official documentation exists, SIF likely stands for Shot/Segment/Span Information File. The precise contents of the file format have not yet been established, but its existence is necessary in order to import spanned clips into Canon media apps.
details.dc:creator: Canon / Canon

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

details.dc:description: OpenDocument (ODF) format is a generic format for office documents, such as text, spreadsheets, presentations, drawings, and databases. It was developed by OASIS, based on the original OpenOffice document format. The format is an open standard, and is supported by a variety of office software packages. ODF is an XML format, which may comprise a single XML document, or a collection of subdocuments within a package. The package format is the commonly used form, and comprises a standard ZIP package containing the XML content and any associated binary data, together with a manifest which lists the package content. An ODF database document contains a relational database. The content is contained in a 'content' xml subdocument. Additional subdocuments contain style information, document metadata, and application-specific settings.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Preservica / Preservica
record_metadata.dc:description: This format can be identified via a container signature in DROID version 6 or later.

signature.name: Apple Partition Map - ISO 9660 - UDF Hybrid Disk Image sig.1
signature.note:
BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: wildcard bytes between 0 to 16 bytes, followed by 0x45520200, an exact 508 wildcard bytes followed by 0x504D
BOF; Offset: 32768; Max Offset: 103236; Magic Bytes: 0x4344303031, then wildcard bytes between 1 to 16384, followed by 0xFF4344303031

signature.name: Apple Partition Map - ISO 9660 - UDF Hybrid Disk Image sig.2udf
signature.note:
BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: wildcard bytes between 0 to 16 bytes, followed by 0x45520800, an exact 2044 wildcard bytes followed by 0x504D
BOF; Offset: 32768; Max Offset: 103236; Magic Bytes: 0x4344303031, then wildcard bytes between 1 to 16384, followed by 0xFF4344303031
BOF; Offset: 32768; Max Offset: 69632; Magic Bytes: 0x00424541303101, then an exact of 2041 wildcard bytes, followed by 0x004E535230, then either 0x32 or 33 followed by 0x01

details.dc:description: Apple Partition Map - ISO 9660 - UDF Hybrid Disk Image, describes the contents and structure of optical disc media of Apple Partition Map (APM) partition scheme with ISO9660 and Universal Disk Format (UDF) file systems attached. Since all three schemes reside on the same optical disc this is most likely to be on DVD media type of file. APM partition scheme can be thought of as a container format for multiple file system image files, and in this entry together UDF file system developed for optical media by the Optical Storage Technology Association (OSTA) and ISO 9660 International Organization for Standardization (ISO), the hybrid system acts as a support for all three schemes and allows for disc to be rendered on various operating systems. A disk image is a uncompressed copy of the contents of a disk or a folder, it can facilitate certain types of backup and recovery strategies. Please see ID: fdd000348 from Library of Congress and other links attached to this entry for further information.

details.dc:description: Media Descriptor File is created by the software Alcohol %120, developed by Alcohol Soft. It is a CD/DVD image format. The Media Descriptor File is often accompanied by a sidecar file with the extension .mds. This file contains metadata and structural information about the disc image. This format supports mixed mode CDs and can contain both audio and data tracks.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Royal Danish Library / The Royal Danish Library

signature.name: Media Descriptor Sidecar File
signature.note: BOF; Offset:0; Magic Bytes: 'MEDIA DESCRIPTOR'

details.dc:description: Media Descriptor Sidecar File contains metadata and structural information about the Media Descriptor File. It is found alongside files with the extension .mdf. These files are created from the software Alcohol %120 which was developed by Alcohol Soft.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Royal Danish Library / The Royal Danish Library

signature.name: CloneCD Control File
signature.note: BOF; Offset:0; Magic Bytes: '[CloneCD]'

details.dc:description: CloneCD Control File is used by the CloneCD software to mark the properties of a CD/DVD image and contains metadata and structural information about the disk image. It is found alongside the .img disk image file. They often have a .sub subchannel file alongside them.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Royal Danish Library / The Royal Danish Library

details.dc:description: MacBinary is a format for the encoding of Macintosh files for transmission or storage on other operating systems. This means that all system specific aspects of the file can be reconstituted after transmission. The file itself combines the two forks of a MacOS file into a single file alongside the metadata.
details.dc:creator: Apple Computer, Inc.

signature.name: Sony SLV File
signature.note: BOF:'slvg' followed by a gap of 4 followed by 'fill'

details.dc:description: A Sony SLV file is automatically generated by some models of Sony cameras when an error occurs during filming, such as a power cut or a media issue or when the camera fails to close properly during an improper shutdown. Although no official documentation has been found, various forum posts claim that SLV stands for salvage and that these files are created to assist the camera in salvaging lost data, by creating an XML file and then auto-deleting after this process is complete.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Media Hash List
signature.note: BOF:'<?xml version=("OR')1.0("OR')' followed by a gap of 0-512 bytes followed by <hashlist version=("OR')1.0("OR')

details.dc:description: The Media Hash List (MHL) standard specifies how a common inventory list of a folder’s content looks like. The Media Hash List specification ensures that the complete source media is transferred without any alterations. MHL is an XML format, that lists all the files in a folder and all of its subfolders as well as the corresponding checksums. This list is accompanied by additional information about the creation of the MHL file. The MHL file comprehends all the information necessary to tell if the folder structure or any of the contained files was modified since the MHL file was created.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Sony SML File
signature.note: BOF:'<list type=' followed by a gap of 0-64 bytes followed by 'name= ; 'EOF:'</list>

details.dc:description:
Sony SML files store housekeeping information used by 7-series cameras, including user-defined settings and lists. They are found in the SOUNDDEV folder in storage volumes formatted by 7-series recorders. More specifically, these files contain the following information:
PROJECTFOLDERS.SML - contains any entry and setting that has been made under the Top-Level Folder selection of the File: Folder Options Setup Menu option.
ROLLFOLDERS.SML - contains any entry and setting that has been made under the Mid-Level Folder selection of the File: Folder Options Setup Menu option.
SCENEFOLDERS.SML - contains any entry and setting that has been made under the Bottom-Level Folder selection of the File: Folder Options Setup Menu option.
SCENENAMES.SML - contains any entry and setting that has been made under the Setup Menu option Rec: Scene Name/Number.
TRKANAME.SML - contains any entry and setting that has been made under the Track A selection of the Rec: Track Names Setup Menu option.
TRKBNAME.SML - contains any entry and setting that has been made under the Track B selection of the Rec: Track Names Setup Menu option.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Digital Preservation Department / The National Archives

signature.name: Calc602 Project File v 1.51
signature.note: BOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes: Software602 Calc602 v.1.51 WorkSpace

details.dc:description: Binary format used by spreadsheet programme Calc602 containing information about all currently open files, layout on the screen, macros loaded into memory etc.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The National Archives of the Czech Republic / The National Archives of the Czech Republic

details.dc:description: File written in C programming language that can be opened and viewed in any text editor. As a source code file, it can be converted into machine language by a compiler, creating an executable program. Since 1989, the language has been standardised by the International Organisation for Standardization (ISO) and ANSI. Programmes written in C can be used in a wide variety of operating systems and computer programmes, if they are standards compliant, with minimal changes to their source code.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Stadtarchiv Hof / Stadtarchiv Hof

details.dc:description: File written in the general-purpose programming language C++, which was created as an extension of the C programming language that developed into a language in its own right. C++ is standardised by the International Organisation for Standardization (ISO), who first standardised it in 1998.

record_metadata.dc:creator: Stadtarchiv Hof / Stadtarchiv Hof

signature.name: GenBank Flat File
signature.note: BOF Absolute from beginning of file, magic bytes: LOCUS Variable: ORIGIN EOF offset 0-1, magic bytes: //.

details.dc:description: The GenBank format was developed by the U.S. National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI). The format is a standardised way of recording DNA and protein sequencing information accompanied with other data, such as Journal references, keywords, definitions and other information, so that it can be easily read by humans and machines. The NCBI Genbank database https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genbank/ is a repository of publicly available DNA sequences in the Genbank format, and takes in submissions of Genbank files from all over the world.
details.dc:creator: National Center for Biotechnology Information

record_metadata.dc:creator: Bodleian Library, University of Oxford / Bodleian Library, University of Oxford

signature.name: Esri Persistent Auxiliary Metadata File
signature.note: BOF offset 0-30, magic bytes: <PAMDataset>(10-200)<Metadata domain="ESRI"|"Esri"> EOF, offset 0-1:</PAMDataset>

details.dc:description: The ESRI Persistent Auxiliary Metadata File is a format produced by ArcGIS software, which accompanies the raster file (and sits alongside it). lnformation for the raster dataset, such a statistics, tables, histograms and co-ordinates, is stored in this auxiliary file if it cannot be stored internally. The files have the extension .aux.xml, but due to limitations of PRONOM, have been added with extension.xml as well as aux.xml.
details.dc:creator: Esri / Esri

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia

signature.name: Casio QV CAM
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: 0x0720 followed by 'MM'

details.dc:description:
Casio QV CAM file format is a proprietary raster image format of Casio QV digital camera series. The QV series camera were originally packaged with built in flash memory to store images with a special data cable that allowed for transfer to a personal computer whilst using the QV-Link software. Using the software, the CAM format allowed for images to be uploaded back to its camera. The format could be considered a camera data image format, as some files contain JFIF or other encoding. The QV-Link software allowed for CAM file to be saved as TIFF, JPEG, or BM format for MS-Windows; or PICT, TIFF, or JPEG for Macintosh.
The first of the series, QV-10, was announced in November 1994 and was originally developed by a team led by Hiroyuki Suetaka in 1995. It was the world's first consumer LCD digital camera, meaning that it was the first electronic camera in history that allowed users to record and view the images right away. The relatively low cost of the camera helped it achieve wide success and was influential in the rise in popularity of digital photography. The full list of QV series can be found following the links provided in Notes section.

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints
