signature.name: Extensible Markup Language v1.1
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: XML header declaration - '<?xml' followed by whitespace character specific to XML file, then either no wildcard characters or up to thirty whitespace characters, then followed by version number. XML 1.1 can incorporate various spaces in its syntax, this possibility has been incorporated to this signature.

details.dc:description: Extensible Markup Language (XML) version 1.1 was developed by World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) in 2004. It is a general purpose markup language for creating other special purpose markup languages, it derived from SGML (ISO 8879). XML 1.1 was designed to be used when features of XML 1.0 [fmt/101] do not permit certain functionalities. It is structured to use any version of Unicode, in basic terms, whereas XML 1.0 provided a rigid definition of names, wherein everything that was not permitted was forbidden, XML 1.1 names are designed so that everything that is not forbidden (for a specific reason) is permitted. It also adds checking of normalization, and follows the Unicode line ending rules more closely. Authors are encouraged to generate XML 1.0 documents if the added flexibility is not required. XML Parsers are expected to understand both XML 1.0 and XML 1.1. It typically begins with an XML declaration, defining the XML version and character set used. This may be followed by a Document Type declaration, containing or pointing to a markup declaration for the class of document. An XML document is said to be well-formed if it conforms to the XML specification; it is said to be valid if it additionally complies with a defined markup declaration. The formatting and transformation of XML documents can be controlled using the Extensible Stylesheet Language (XSL).
details.dc:creator: World Wide Web Consortium

record_metadata.dc:creator: Stadtarchiv Hof / Stadtarchiv Hof

details.dc:description: Software-Independent Archiving of Relational Databases is a format for storing content of relational databases in files for long-term preservation e.g. in archives. The format was developed by the Swiss Federal Archives. It is an open standard and is supported by the SIARD software of the Swiss Federal Archives. SIARD format is a ZIP file (based on the 64 bit extension of the ZIP format introduced by PkWare Inc. with version 4.5 of the ZIP format definition in order to avoid size limitations which are unrealistic for databases). The ZIP file contains an XML file describing the database structure and metadata as well as a collection of XML files describing the table content (database primary data) as well as, optionally, some text files and some binary files representing database large objects (BLOBs and CLOBs).
details.dc:creator: Swiss Federal Archives / Swiss Federal Archives

record_metadata.dc:creator: Swiss Federal Archives / Swiss Federal Archives
record_metadata.dc:description: This format is identifiable via a container signature in DROID 6 and later.

signature.name: Pentax PEF Image File
signature.note: BOF; Offset: 0; Magic Bytes: A TIFF based format starting with TIFF Motorola endian header "MM.*" then variable number of wildcard bytes followed by 'PENTAX' tag, then wildcard bytes between none to 2048 followed by MakerNote values of "AOC MM".

details.dc:description: Pentax PEF Image File (or Pentax RAW) is a RAW image format based on TIFF [fmt/353] file format, provided by Pentax and associated with Pentax Digital SLR cameras. Its use has been deprecated since the release of DNG format. Similarly to RAW camera formats, PEF format contains information of image capture such as colour, lighting or camera sensor. The structure of these informations related to each image differs in each PEF format depending on which camera model was used to capture the image. The format first appeared with Pentax's digital *its Series and continued until Pentax Q series.
details.dc:creator: Ricoh / Ricoh

record_metadata.dc:creator: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints / The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints

signature.name: The Spectral Geologist Dataset v.7.15
signature.note: BOF 0-1024, magic bytes: TSG 7.15 Dataset

details.dc:description: File generated by The Spectral Geologist (TSG), processing software designed for the analysis of field or laboratory spectrometer data. TSG stores the spectral and associated data (geochemistry, coordinate data etc) in two files, regardless of the number of spectra in the dataset. These files have the extensions .bip and .tsg. The .bip file stores all of the spectral and associated data; it is usually far larger than the .TSG file. The .tsg file stores a description of the data contained in the associated .BIP file. Both files are essential for TSG to be able to access the dataset and must be together in the same directory.
details.dc:creator: The Spectral Geologist

record_metadata.dc:creator: National Library of Australia / National Library of Australia
